reviewText: I purchased this television to replace an old, old bedroom tv.  I cannot say enough good things about the Samsung line of televisions.  At the same time I purchased this one, I also purchased a 40 inch.This television (the 26 inch) has a high quality picture vs. our 26 inch Sony.  This television "hands down" outdoes my Sony in sound, picture quality and adjustment features. In fact, if you stand to the side of our Sony, the picture becomes very blurry--not so with the Samsung.The menu is very user friendly and I really like the fact that you can set the volume to adjust with channel changes.  Our cable system is such that some stations are much louder than others.  With a quick adjustment on the Samsung, that no longer is a problem.Amazon's shipping is so fast and free shipping is sure a plus.  We actually paid less for this television than we did for our Sony and this is a better television.I would absolutely recommend this television to any looking for a high quality flat screen.  I just recommended a Samsung to a friend, who went to an "unnamed" store to see it in person and was very impressed.
summary: Cannot say enough good things about Samsung televisions

reviewText: First of all the battery is very sleek.  I like the incremental led light in the front and the fact that there are no buttons you simply pick it up and it turns on and lights up to display the charge.  It is compact enough to fit in your pocket so you could charge your phone on the go easily.  I charged my phone up to full and the leds did not even go to halfway so i know this thing is raited as it claims.  It also charges pretty fast.  I noticed after a long charge it does not get hot or even warm to the touch.  My cheap external battery i have gets burning hot.So all in all i would consider it a great product.  It seems smaller than comparable 6000mah battery packs.  I like the fact it is able to detect the product you are trying to charge and bump up to the amperage automatically such as phone vs a tablet.If you are looking for a portable battery this is THE ONE to get.  Stop looking at other ones and brands.  Heck for the price nothing even compares.I paired this with the Anker 1A usb wall charger to make sure i always charge it properly to ensure a long life.
summary: Best portable charger I have used

reviewText: The sound of this speaker system is great for the price.  It isn't going to wow any audiophiles though, as the center and satellite speakers are a bit weak on the low end to pick up where the sub-woofer leaves off.  In fact, the sub-woofer overpowers the satellites very easily.  What is cool is that the sub-woofer has its own volume control, so you can tune it down separately for "evening" listening.  (Or turn it up for partying!)I was a little disappointed in the speaker wire that came with the package.  I got about 100 feet of wire, which was barely enough to run my rear surround speakers to the back of the room. The wire is very thin--probably around 20-22 guage.  Too thin to use my wire strippers, so I had to resort to the old razor blade around once and pull with teeth technique.  In fact, the speaker wire is too thin for the connections on some of the speakers, slipping out loosely instead of being held down by the clamp action of the connector.  I doubled up the wire so that it was thick enough to hold.  I also put an order in for decent speaker wire.By the way, there is no way to hook this up directly to a computer or television.  You need an amplifier/receiver as only the sub-woofer is amplified.Given the price, I am still happy with the purchase.
summary: Nice but comes with very thin speaker wire

reviewText: The first thing you'll notice after removing the pen from it's elegant packaging is it's look and feel. The "gun metal" color is very high-tech looking, and the feel - wow. It's weighty, but not uncomfortably so, and the finish is "grippy." That surprised me - I thought it would be slippery from the look.The "stylus" is actually a silicone rubber "bubble" on the cap. I call it a bubble because it's not solid.  This way it "gives" and won't scratch your screen. It only works with capacitive touchscreens (pretty much all modern devices) - not with screens that use the hard stylus.  The "bubble" replicates the feel and size of a small finger - pretty cool. It's also pretty tough. I tried picking it off - no go. It would take some effort to remove or tear it.It's also the small things - the parts fit together perfectly. The pen cartridge compartment is O-ring sealed. The pen tip is a rollerball style, and is spring cushioned. The only thing they cheaped-out on is the clip. It could be better. For a shirt or jacket pocket, it's fine. For a thicker material - say a jeans pocket, it would be iffy.Mine came with blue ink, not black as pictured.
summary: High quality, excellent feel - no more screen scratches

There's only 6 major points where the case clings to the tablet: the 4 corners and one at the top right and one bottom right (if the camera is top-center). The tablet isn't completely encased, so drops will definitely still pose a threat towards a cracked screen or chipped side.Feature-wise, it allows you to stand the N7 landscape 3 different angles to assist with watching videos, viewing pictures, or typing. The front cover (as updated by the manufacturers) contains the magnet that allows the N7 to wake/sleep upon opening/closing. It also has 2 elastic bands, which is why I put '...Hopefully" in my title.When you flip the front cover around there's one elastic band you use as a handle to help keep your butterfingers from letting go of the N7 and smashing it on the ground. Now the other elastic band I'm being wary of. It's also on the front cover, but it's used to wrap around the front of the tablet on the top left and bottom right. The middle section then wraps around this curved part of the front cover. Now I've only been using this case for less than even half a day and that elastic band already seems outstretched. It may return to its previous state, but long-term I'd really want to keep my eye on it.Other than that, it's a great first/only (so far) case I've bought for the N7.

We received a Garmin 1450 for Christmas (great gift!) but after one 7 hour trip (with several stops) we decided the enclosed window suction cup type mount had to go. Although our 2010 Corolla does not have a flat dash, the mount holds our 1450 perfectly. Very easy to attach the GPS unit & just as easy to seperate.  Ideal when making a pit stop - can quickly remove the GPS from the friction mount, and hide both & then reassemble to continue the trip.  Just one heads up - we have noticed after long trips the dash looks "scratched" where friction mount sat. These "scratches" buff out easily - not permanent damage, just slight scuffing that disappears with a little elbow grease. Bottom line, buy it - you'll  be very happy with this product. Thanks Amazon !

Philips has been debuting a number of headphones for different lifestyles recently, and The Bend is clearly aimed at those with active lifestyles. These headphones are designed to take a beating, yet still provide better than average audio fidelity.The Bend headphones are very light, made out of a plastic that is extremely flexible. You can stretch these until they are practically flat. Reinforced cables and a safe release feature for the cans provide more protection. Finally, Philips built in a feature that helps protect the headphone cable, which is cloth-covered. The cable connects to the headphone via a 3.5mm stereo headphone jack, so if it gets caught on something, the cable will break-away, and not damage the headphones. Philips has promised to replace the cable if you lose it. Additionally, the cloth-covered cable will not tangle.Now, about the sound. The 30mm drivers provide balanced sound. Bass is not deep and thumping, although these are advertised as headphones that provide powerful bass. I have used them for about 20 hours, so they may not be fully burned in yet, and bass may improve with usage. Both the mid-range and treble are clear and sharp. Nothing really overwhelms or distorts. The ear padding is very thick and pillow-like (and comfortable) and I have not experienced any discomfort with the plastic headband. These headphones sit on top of your ears, not over them, so sound isolation is average at best, which means you will hear the roar of the train or plane. And, if you are using these in a quiet room, there may be some sound leakage.I would recommend these headphones, especially if you are looking for decent sounding headphones that you can throw into a backpack or an overnight bag. While the bass is not deep (as advertised), for the price The Bend produces decent sound and durability.
summary: Good Travel Headphones That are True to Their Name

The Grado R1si has been a legendary headphone for many years. This new R1i improves on the sound of the old RS1 with more detail and better bass performance. I bought these after sort of lusting after them for MANY years. Probably 15 years or so or whenever these were released. I already owned the newer PS-500, which are 5 star phones without question. The R1si arrived and my 1st thought was "wow, the packing box is nicer than the PS-500" - then when I opened the box the beauty of the headphones struck me instantly. They are absolutely gorgeous. AND they are incredibly light. MUCH lighter feeling in my hands and head than the PS500. I was thinking...man, even if these sound awful I will keep them for the looks as they look great with my RA1 amp.Yes, I own the RA1 amp paired with a DAC feeding high res files from my mac. The amp is a perfect mate for my PS500 so I assumed it would be even better with the R1si.My 1st listening test ... I was hugely disapointed. Gone was the rich, liquid, sensual and full sound of my PS500. It was replaced with a sharp, dry, and hard to take midrange that was excessively forward. I let then burn in for a while..and each time I came back to them they sounded a teeny bit better but even still, they were no match sonically for the $100 less expensive PS-500. They look better, they feel better and  they come with the extra cables and better box but for sound, the PS500 rule the roost.PS500 at $595 is a steal of a deal. They provide a rich, detailed but warm, thick and sexy sound while giving a nice wide soundstage (though not as wide as the PS1000 or HD800). The R1si's seem a bit closed in, lack the soundstage and are a bit sharp. Female vocals turned up loud will pierce through your brain. Rock is too bright. If i did not have the PS500s to compare i would not know any better and I would probably get used to the R1si sound and be happy but side by side it was no contest.I appreciate the RS1i's for the look design and style (which I love) but you can do better for less. If you want them partly for the wood and look then they are worth it as they do sound good, just not as good as others.PROS:LightGorgeous dark wood colorDetails are thereGreat for acoustic guitarIt's legendary :)Conversation startersNice thick cableEasy to driveCONS:Fragile buildMy copy had the drivers reversed so I had to disassemble to correct this. 2 minute job but where is the QC?Fatiguing sound, even with the matching RA1 amp and burn in (when compared to the $100 less PS-500)$200 to expensive IMOIf you like a sharp forward midrange sound these are for you. If you like a warmer but detailed rich sound with soundstage, the PS500's can not be beat for $595
summary: The PS-500 is Leagues better for $100 less, I have both

reviewText: I looked at and read reviews on several GoPro cases before choosing this one.  Two main reasons I made this choice was that (1) the description made it clear that the foam dunnage was made to accommodate the Hero 3+, which I have and (2) the lid compartment (which most all of the GoPro cases have) is in this case zippered.  If you like what is stated in the description and like what the case looks like in the photos, then you will be happy with this case.  It is true to the description and photos.  I have my Hero 3+ with quick release buckle attached, two spare batteries and their charger (Wasabi Power), the Wi-Fi Remote, an X-Lapse "egg timer" pano gadget with the iPhone holder that came with it and the memory card adapter all in the main compartment.  Cables in the lid compartment.  There's no way I wanted a case big enough to carry all the mounts, etc that I will probably collect over time, so I'm also happy with the size.  I wasn't looking for the absolute minimum size case either.  This one holds all of the essentials and is very portable.  Good protection all around and recommended.

reviewText: Am good with computers, software so I should be able to set this up fast.Well, not quite. Tried all the options as the instruction, but nothing showed up on Win-7 windows.There was an alternative setup that worked and suggest not wasting time and aggravate yourself and follow this.-Get a network short cable.-plug in the device.-plug in to your computer by removing your cable going to the router.-disable your WIFI if connected-Screen should pop up for the Amp device.BTW, your virus software may pop up and inform you that you have no security with the AMP WIFI.Ignore it for now until the setup finished.All you have to do is follow the steps below.It will ask you to create a password but as it says it will NOT CHANGE the router's setting/password.I'd say use the same password you use for the router access, or the WIFI from the router. Your choice. I use the router password.Make sure you follow all the prompts and FINISH the setup!Then, unplug the cable on both ends, plug in your LAN cable from the router.The LAN setup should show now in the WIFI section your have an AMPED device.Now, you can move the AMPED device anywhere and try it. If one place don't work well, go to another.It works well and no issues at all.A note:Many complained it won't work, ETC, it is NOT compatible with cable modems/router and you have to find out from your provider if they can give you the model AMPED recommends.For the rest of us using regular LAN it's no issue
summary: works like a charm but the setup is a little difficult

I guess I am another buyer who was influenced by all of the rave reviews for this speaker. I mean, some of the reviews are absolutely glowing.Here's my take. Right off the bat, I thought the sound was a little muddy ... or muffled ... both. I really expected more clarity than this speaker puts out. When adjusted to a level that I prefer to listen to, the high notes just aren't clear. However, things get better when you increase the volume, and I must say that for such a small speaker it really can fill a room with sound.At first, I thought my initial disappointment was due to the fact that I own a home theater system with sound that can put most movie theaters to shame. But realizing that that was a very unfair comparison, I decided to compare the Supersonic bluetooth speaker with another small speaker I own: the Altec Lansing Music Speaker --Altec Lansing iM 207 SpeakerThis confirmed my suspicions. The Altec Lansing produced crisp highs and midtones, but very little bass. Still, it still sounds better to me for all-around listening. The disadvantage is that this speaker is not wireless; you have to plug it in to your sound source. Also, the Altec requires 3 AAA batteries, and is not rechargeable by itself (but you can use rechargeable batteries).The cool factor for the Supersonic is that it is wireless. The bluetooth connected very quickly, and it picks up the signal from my iPod from halfway across the house.By the way, I plugged my Altec speaker into the output port of my Supersonic speaker, and with both of them playing together, the sound was much improved. The only strange thing is that when I did this, the volume on both speaker units dropped very low. I don't understand this, since they both have their own power supply.As far as build quality, the Supersonic appears very well put together. No complaints here. The speaker does not come with a charging block, only the cable. But it appears you can use any USB charging unit -- such as the one that came with my iPod.Overall, I think the speaker is a cool gadget, and I hope to get lots of use out of it. But don't expect it blow you away with high fidelity sound. It's not able to, and, at this small size, should not be expected to.
summary: Cool little speaker ... but I expected better

reviewText: I own a Nikon D3s (full frame sensor), and have found the recommended Type 3 swab to be extremely frustrating to use in the tight space of the camera chamber, and often ineffective.  As other reviewers have pointed out, the supposedly dust-free, lint-free swab often ends up leaving residual fibers on the sensor and in the chamber, compounding the issues around cleaning it effectively.I often must use 2-4 swabs to clean the sensor, and sometimes there is still a small dust spec that I'm afraid to go after with yet another swab, for fear of depositing more stuff on the sensor.  There has got to be a better substance for the swab that won't leave residual fibers.  Unfortunately, I've tried one other swab manufacturer with a blue fiber head, and it was even worse than this brand.I may try going back to the smaller Type 2 swab to see if it will work better, knowing that it is going to take more than one swab to do the job, regardless.  I've been cleaning my digital sensors for years, dating back to my former cropped sensor cameras.  I use a sensor scope for the procedure so that I can effectively see whether the sensor is clean.  I found the smaller sensors much easier to clean with the smaller swabs.Realistically, be prepared to be frustrated with the cleaning procedure.  Unfortunately, the alternative is a trip to a photographic store that you trust, or shipping your camera back to your manufacturer for an expensive factory cleaning.
summary: Frustrating to use and often ineffective

You can read about all the cool features of this GPS in the other reviews.  But compared to my 3-year-old Garmin Nuvi 200 (the cheapest modern GPS you can buy), it comes up short.  The only reason I wanted a new GPS was to get one that could read street names out loud.  This Moto has way more features than I needed but I saw a good lightning deal price so I decided to give it a try.  I'm sending it back and ordering another Garmin!The display is better on the Garmin: the colors have better contrast, and the road names are easier to read.  The voice is also clearer on the Garmin and louder (perhaps a smaller speaker on the Moto?).  This is a concern for me since I drive a diesel truck and I need something LOUD.Also, one of the best features of Garmin is their super-simple user interface.  On the Garmin, if I want to find banks near me, it's as simple as clicking a big button that says "Banks/ATMs".  On the Moto, I have to type the name of the bank I'm looking for or, (I finally discovered) I can type the word "bank" and then open the right-side panel, click on the tab to sort by category, and click on the "Banks" category.  And the Moto seems to have a pre-set limit on the number of matches it will show you.  If the Bank you want is a little farther away from your current position, too bad.  The Garmin just keeps them coming as long as you keep scrolling.  The Garmin has the simplest, most elegant user interface by far.I will give the Moto credit for one amazingly cool feature: you can add as many waypoints to your route as you like, and you can *drag*and*drop* them to reorder them!  This could be a very very valuable feature for some users.  The Garmin (at least the inexpensive ones) allow one via point on the way to your final destination.In 2008 I was on a road trip and I damaged the screen on my Garmin.  I stopped at the nearest Big Box and purchased a Magellan.  I ended up selling the Magellan on eBay when I got home because I couldn't stand the interface.  Luckily, this time all I have to do is return the Moto to Amazon.  I'll stick with Garmin from now on (I've just ordered a 265WT).
summary: Lots of features but Motorola blew the basics

reviewText: I spend most of my day at a computer writing code and typing emails (or similar) so I wanted to try a premium mechanical keyboard like this one.Now that I'm used to it, I really like it. The Cherry MX Blue switches feel good--crisp, tactile, high-quality. At times, I do feel like I can type faster and with less effort/thought with this keyboard than with a regular rubber dome keyboard. Regular keyboards now feel too mushy to me and I avoid them. I also appreciate how this particular keyboard has a nice premium soft-touch coating, and it doesn't take up any more space than it needs to--there's very little overhang past the keys in any direction. I got the model with very little branding--just some on the front (facing the monitor) which I can't see when I'm using it. The font used on the keys is a little "gamer-y" (it looks like the Battlestar Galactica logo) but I rarely look at the keyboard while I'm typing so it doesn't bother me at all. The paint on the keys is pretty thick and I can feel it while I'm typing, but it doesn't bother me. I expect it to wear off after a while, which is something that other reviewers have complained about. I can see how this could be considered a poor design decision and not acceptable for such an expensive keyboard, but I'm only concerned with how well the keyboard works (not looks) so I'm not going to deduct any stars.As I alluded to earlier, the keyboard did take some getting used to, at least if you're coming from a rubber dome keyboard. The keyboard is taller than almost any rubber dome keyboard, and the keys are taller and have more travel, and there is no built-in wrist rest. So if you rest your wrists on your desk (I know you're not supposed to, but I do), you will have to bend them at a sharper angle, which might cause some wrist pain. Also, many keyboards these days have smooth edges on the keys at the bottom, e.g., the edge where your thumb rests on the spacebar. This keyboard does not, so the side of your thumb might get sore. I also wasn't used to keys with so much travel and initially my fingers were getting "stuck" between the keys and that caused a lot of typos. But I will say that after ~2 weeks of using the keyboard, I have adapted to it and I have no unusual wrist pain or thumb soreness, and I can type as accurately with it as any other keyboard I've used.There are a couple more possible negatives to mention, which may or may not be important to you. One is the amount of noise the keyboard makes. You quickly get used to it, but the people around you might not. I think it's likely not appropriate for an open office environment. (One more thing about the noise: sometimes it makes a slight "ringing" noise after you're done typing something... one more thing to get used to.) The keyboard is also relatively heavy. I didn't realize how often I repositioned my keyboard during the day until I got this keyboard, which is pretty inconvenient to reposition.Ultimately, if you're in the market for a mechanical keyboard, I think this particular one is a great buy. It's less expensive ($30+) than most of its direct competition and it doesn't have any downsides that the other keyboards wouldn't also have. It also doesn't have some of the deal-breaking design flaws that some of them do have, like flimsy USB connectors that are prone to breaking, or a different switch type for the space bar that feels weird, etc. Overall I think it's a great purchase and I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it to others.
summary: Good keyboard, takes a little getting used to

The vertical slot alignment might allow them to cram more ports onto an expansion slot but it won't work for all cases.Another issue is that the item is called "5 port USB" and "3 port firewire", but only 4 USB ports and only 2 firewire ports are actually available after it's installed. The other two are inside and so only accomodate the installation of a permanent device. So this ad leads you to believe you're getting 8 ports when really, you're only getting 6.The upside is, the ports all seem to work and Windows 7 recognized the card without needing to have drivers installed.All in all, I would not buy it again.

I had been disappointed with how sluggish my 6Mb DSL felt, but I assumed it was just because I had come from 20Mb cable. No, it turns out it was just this modem--or rather, the router portion of this modem. Port forwarding did work for me, but not as well as I'd have liked. It appears it doesn't support NAT loopback, so my web server was accessible from the internet, but not from my LAN. Same issue with the web server as a DMZ. I finally got annoyed, switched the modem over to bridge mode, and dusted off my ancient WRT54G running tomato. Pages load much faster now and YouTube videos don't have buffering issues. There don't seem to be many modems compatible with CenturyLink's service, so I guess this modem might still be worth considering, but only for use with a competent router.

reviewText: I intended this device for use on my home-built Windows 7 Home entertainment/gaming PC, but first tested it in an Alienware MX17 laptop running Windows 7 Pro.- Setup Software -The Belkin Wireless N USB adapter was really easy to install and setup. I hate the wireless adapters that attempt to replace the Windows 7 interface for managing wireless networks with a custom one. This does not attempt that. It's only so much bloat-ware, so you're better off without it.There was a moment during installation that I realized that it was dropping software directories in the 32-bit installation directory of my 64-bit OS, but before I had time to get annoyed about it, the installation program completed unpacking all it's files, checked to see what version of the OS I was using and deleted all the other driver directories leaving only the Win7 64-bit driver installation package behind. The installation software prompts you to install the USB device when it's ready, and shortly afterwards there is a system reboot.- Hardware Installation  -My main complaint about this device is the form-factor. The wireless adapter is a direct plug USB device which unfortunately will block access to any adjacent USB ports.The ports on my laptop where I tried this are on both sides of the machine, one set horizontal, the other vertical. The Belkin USB wireless device blocked an adjacent port no matter which side I tried it on.Also, be aware that it does stick out a good 2 inches or so - mobile users will have to take care that the device is not knocked or leaned on while in the port as that will cause damage to the USB adapter, the port or the motherboard of your laptop. This was destined for a stationary tower PC, so was not a concern for me, but notebook users should be aware.- Performance -The wireless adapter got an excellent signal through a concrete cinderblock wall that separates me from the wireless router I use. I was on a G signal, not an N, and got excellent signal strength and a steady 54mbps.  My normal wireless adapter is a Dell DW150 half-mini card installed inside my laptop. This test was promising enough that I was willing to install the Belkin on my entertainment center PC which currently has an old Linksys wireless card with a massive antenna.Final Installation - Or Where it All Fell Apart.The problem with the size of the Belkin N150 became apparent when installing it on a rear panel USB port of my entertainment center PC. It blocks other nearby ports which are currently in use. On my tower PC motherboard (As with most motherboards) the on-board USB ports are all close together. In this case, the Belkin adapter would either not fit, or block two adjacent USB ports, or one and a firewire port. I also have a rear extension panel, where I tried the device next, except that it blocked the second port of that as well.I did pull out devices from the adjacent port to try it, and also try the Belkin on a couple front panel ports. While I could get the hardware recognized by WIndows, I could not get a wireless signal on the tower. Both the laptop and tower are in the same room.- Conclusion -I must conclude that there is something about my entertainment PC hardware or software that does not like this device. Though the intended use on my  tower PC was impossible, on my laptop, the installation and performance on a 802.11g network were flawless and aside from the size of the device, make for a good recommendation. This device could be improved by designing it so that other nearby ports can still be put to use.
summary: Good Wireless N Adapter. Inconvenient size.

I bought this unit from a different location.  I owned it for less than a week.  Of note, I owned a TOMTOM before.I am not sure why this unit keeps getting rave reviews, but I am sure that those rating it are going by the available features and not actually USING the unit.1.  It will NOT recognize left turns.  Let's say your destination is a shopping area on the right.  There are plenty of stop lights to turn left to get you to your destination.  But for some reason, the unit will have you turn right into a completely different shopping area, then cross a busy intersection to get to your destination.  At first I thought it because I had "AVOID U TURNS" selected (even though it wasn't a U turn) but even after disabling that feature, it continued to do it.  And at 3 different destinations!! I don't know if that is true for every destination (since I only had it for a week and some destinations were on the right) but it did it for EVERY LEFT TURN... even after I upgraded the maps.2.  I wasn't happy with the lack of customizable features for the map or even the settings in general.  Perhaps the worst was the fact that on the map it showed estimated ARRIVAL TIME (which was always wrong but would correct it self as the minutes would pass).  There is no way to get useful information on the screen like miles remaining in trip.3.  The traffic was useless.  It never detected serious traffic until you were sitting bumper-to-bumper in it and it would frequently say there was traffic when there was none. No wonder its free.Those are deal breakers for me.The things I did like1.  TTS (but that's not unique to Garmin)2.  Automatic power on and off if connected to car via cord (I think that is unique to Garmin)3.  Auto option for day and night maps (again, I think that is unique to Garmin).4.  They (Garmin and TomTom) both allow for map updates, but Garmin is cheaper (lifetime is $120 - which is 4 maps per year vs. TomTom's $80 per year).Never used the bluetooth, so I can't comment.  I have a centro which can't do voice dialing via BT anyway so it was no biggie for me.Overall, I hated the unit.  It was lacking in everything that I found necessary for function.
summary: Awful, horrible unit...why is it getting such great reviews?

A needed a compact monopod for travel so I clicked on the Sirui P-326. A handsome monopod with impeccable workmanship landed in my mailbox: quality materials, ultra clean fit and finish and silky smooth moving parts. The low rez product images on Amazon don't do it justice. It's a mere 15 inches retracted, easily fitting in a bike messenger or camera bag. And, at barely 1/2 pound, weighs about the same as a compact umbrella.  A few seconds of twisting and it's fully extended. One reviewer is able to twist all 6 leg locks at once. However, my average sized mitts can only twist 3 or 4 of them at once. I'm 5'8' and, when fully extended, the P-326 is too tall for me with DSLR attached, so I leave the smallest section retracted.MOUNTING CAMERAS: I love the reversible 1/4 to 3/8 mounting stud and disk with built-in nut wrench, making for fast switching between a head or direct mounting on the disk. The design is simple but shows the care and thought that went into engineering. I don't have gear anywhere near the 22LB rating of this 'pod, but it has no problem supporting my EOS 6D and EF 300 4L USM.  This is a solid stick: no flex, slipping or play in the leg sections. The leg locks are strong enough for this 'pod to serve as a walking stick and don't flinch when I lean my mighty 140 LB frame into them. I'm hoping I can sneak this guy into places not allowing tripods, and using it as a cane sounds like a plan! Although the P-326 is wee when retracted, the leg sections are far less slip prone than my big bruiser "nightstick" Manfrotto 679B, a longer and heavier monopod.I use a small quick release clamp so I don't have to waste time screwing and unscrewing my camera. TheSUNWAYFOTO Discal Clamp DDY-58 DDY58 ARCA Compatibleis a perfect match for the P-326, being the same color and diameter as the monopod disk (58mm). It fits perfect and appears integral to the design. I wouldn't mind a ball head for museum and church interiors but the idea with a travel stick is to keep it small and light, hence only an Arca clamp.CARRYING THE P-326: The Sirui comes with a light duty hand-strap, a wee compass (!) and an aluminum keychain grade carabiner for attaching to a belt loop or bag. The strap threads into an aluminum retainer beneath the disk and is easy to change, remove or upgrade. If you use the carabiner I recommend upgrading to a stainless steel locking carabiner so you don't lose the P-326 on a mountain trail or noisy sidewalk. For city trekking I use aMAGLITE ASXD036 Plain Leather Belt Holder for D-Cell Flashlight, Blackflashlight holster: loose enough to quickly draw or holster, more stable on my leg than a carabiner and holds securely as long as I don't do flips or handstands. At $5 it's a bargain, especially compared to the bulkyGitzo GC5330 Series 1-5 Monopod Holsterselling for $40. My wife informed me a monopod on my belt looks nerdy but sure is handy.The P-326 is the best stick I've ever owned and highly recommended!
summary: Light, compact, stable & really well made!

reviewText: I have had this product - 2 sets actually - for well over a year and have had ZERO problems. Quality of video, latency, A/V sync are no issues. Have tried all its inputs and outputs at resolutions ranging from 480p to 1080p (I use it mainly in 1080p mode with HDMI). Get a range of over 100 feet reliably in open areas and about 30-40 ft reliably when there are walls and multiple floors in the way. One NEGATIVE is that the product does not do well when you have dense floors or walls such as thick ceramic tiled ones or ones with a lot of metal. This is NOT a ding against the product since I believe it is a physics issue with the 802.11n technology that is at the core of its wireless part. Also, the product does get warm when positioned horizontally without much space beneath or above it. Recommend using it in the vertical position with about 2-inch space around.I have used the product at weddings and events and can attest to its reliability. Don't hesitate to spend the extra money, you'd be glad you did.
summary: Excellent product..no problems for over a year...worth the extra money!

[edited 4/09/06 for some final thoughts]This review is based on over six months of daily use and two road trips through much of the western USA and Canada.First, this software with the Holux GPSlim 236 is what I should have bought. The Tomtom GPS receiver is pretty, but the necessity of switching it on each time you use it (rather than it coming on with external power) has made it a pain to own and I'm going to toss it in a drawer or donate it to a GPSless friend.I use a Dell Axim X51v, so performance is not an issue, even on thousand mile routes the initial route calculation only takes a few seconds.Installation. The installation was simple and trouble free. I had heard that getting the product registered might be an issue but as soon as I connected my PDA to the internet and entered the key I got authorized. I guess the individual state maps are on the rest of the CDs, I only needed the installation and the first two map CDs. For myself I'd rather this had been on a DVD. By comparison iGuidance Europe, which is on a DVD, took two trips to the Internet to search for help and quite a bit of messing with the Bluetooth connection before it could see the receiver.Connecting. If the application is started whilst Bluetooth is disabled on the PDA it simply enables it and connects. Other than waiting a few seconds there has never been an issue with the Bluetooth initerface. If you need to pair it the code is 0000. If you need to use a different GPS then tap the screen, hit "change preferences" then three right arrows and then "show GPS status". Hit the "Configure", use the arrows to select the right hardware and hit Select. Easy. In iGuidance I had to add the receiver as an 'outgoing' serial connection and then tell it which com port had been assigned.The hardware works reasonably well, the Bluetooth receiver has mostly locked on fast and stayed locked everywhere except inside tunnels and a ferry, and even there it managed to receive a couple of satellites (how?). Twice the lock on has taken more than ten minutes, I have no clue why, the satellite display showed around eight good signals but it just didn't lock on. A selling point of the hardware is that it shuts off if the Bluetooth link is down for more than a few minutes. That is sensible, no point running the battery down. But there's a down side, if you want to put the receiver somewhere where it can get a good signal, like on the rear parcel shelf and plugged into a power socket in the trunk, then you'd rather not have to climb in the back each time you get in the car to switch on the receiver. In the long run this may be a killer for me, units like the Holux GPSlim236 can be plugged in and forgotten, they can also take an external antenna which the Tomtom can't... though to be fair it shows no sign of needing it either, in the middle of the first floor of a 300' wide multi floor parking structure it still locked onto six satellites.The 3D and normal map displays are both useful, however the zoom controls only last a few seconds and then the map returns to showing only a small section of road ahead. The zoom seems to be controlled partially by proximity to your next turn and partly by local road details, so in urban areas you get about a quarter of a mile. Perhaps they did this for safety, but in that case they shouldn't have provided the controls. In cities this is ok but when you are driving around rural areas it doesn't let you see the area around you, so you can't see if your route is sensible. I have taken to using the browse map view and then moving it as I drive in rural areas. I should be able to zoom the display until it shows a level of detail that is useful to me and it should stay there. When zoomed out the map display does continue to show useful detail, iGuidance drops too many map features and if you are on small remote roads can leave you looking at a blank screen.There are many choices for map colors and it's easy to get day and night color schemes that give good contrast and visibility. You can also choose from several clear male and female voice options, in English these include US, English and Australian accents. Terminology tracks accent, so if you choose English English you get motorways instead of freeways; amusing but not a problem.The text at the bottom of the screen can show the next turn, speed, distance to go, current time, time to go and eta. The choices are configurable, but nothing like the twenty or thirty that Garmin allowed you to choose from six years ago. The text is very small, I have good eyes and I really have to look hard to see the figures. If I'm 400 miles from my next turn I need to know that a lot more than I need to know I'm going to be turning left when I get there. For this sort of price it should be possible to have more control of the information displayed. iGuidance shows even less information and gives you less control. But this is another case where Garmin had a better solution six years ago.Touching the lower right corner brings up the overview of the route, this should have pan/zoom controls and be in the day/night color scheme. For a trip of several hundred miles it's hardly possile to make out the route on the full VGA display of the X51v.The options for finding a destination are easy to use, the ones I have needed were address, city center, POI and point on map. The routing is also non-volatile, so you can stop for the night and resume in the morning.  One strange thing is that the previous destinations are stored per map, so if you route to a city on the major roads map and then switch to a more detailed map the destination isn't on the list of recent destinations. The unit exhibits a common problem to north american products, you can't route between countries, you can't ask for a route from Calgary Alberta to Salt Lake City Utah because there isn't a map that has both cities. If you want to route from Bute Montana to Idaho Falls Idaho you have to use the major roads map because the states are on different major maps, west and plains. Worth bearing in mind if you live on a border.Trip time predictions are very poor. For a trip from Alameda CA to Port Angeles WA the initial prediction was around 18 hours, which means they are using an average speed of around 50mph. That may be reasonable for I880 on a Monday at 9am but it's 50% out for I5 in northern california. The actual duration was about 14 hours including stops for food and fuel and a visit to Hertz in Portland, OR. On smaller roads the errors are much larger. For the Nephi UT to Tonopah, NV the predicted time was over eight hours and the actual trip time was just over four. On major rural roads in Canada with a 60mph limit the trip times appear to be based on a 30mph average.Routing is fast and the suggested route is certainly in the right direction, but there are issues related to poor choices of road speeds. The software works out the time taken for various routes based on the average speeds for those road classes, but the low freway and major road settings lead it to choose apparently shorter routes through urban areas, this means that it avoids fast roads like US101. In Calgary it routed my south for miles on city streets when I was only half a mile from Deerfoot Trail which is a 65mph road with no stop lights and ultimately becomes I15 at the border. There are also minor weirdnesses, on my daily commute I take I880 south from Oakland CA to San Jose CA, at I238 it directs me to take the off ramp, then then on ramp back to I880. Strangely, if you start from a different place it is able to route you straight down I880 without detouring to the off ramp. Mostly the routes aren't bad though, but Garmin did it better five years ago.Rerouting: If you ask for an alternate route it seeks an alternate for all of the route. So if you are going from Oakland, CA to Seattle, WA and get stuck in traffic trying to get to the freeway and ask for another route it will not only change the entrance onto the freeway, it will also reroute the rest of the trip, so instead of a long day on I5 you may find yourself on a three day drive up the coast. The simple solution is to divert until you are past the problem and then to resubmit the original destination.There are some major mapping errors, much of the time in Canada and Montana the mapped road position was tens or even hundreds of yards from the actual position. This causes the software to either show you driving through open fields near the road, or down the wrong side of a freeway, or even down the frontage road hundreds of yards away on the far side of the freeway in Banff national park. This causes some strange voice directions too, like "turn around when possible" when you are driving down I15 at 70mph and have been going the right way for hours and have to keep going straight ahead for hours. Most city streets in the US are spot on though. But the maps do seem to be 2-4 years out of date.POI problems. The POI list is very lacking. Maybe half to two thirds of gas stations are missing. But worse is the method of selecting POIs. You can look up stores by name, but in the case of the major chains you can get quite a few hits. In places like the San Francisco Bay Area there's a world of difference between somewhere 11 miles down I880 and ten miles across the bay, the first is a 22 mile round trip and the second could be 70. All you get is a list of stores with distances, no address, no direction. So you can't tell which 15 mile distant place they are in. If you select the wrong one and thereby discover that you need to drive thirty miles and cross a toll bridge to get there then there's no back button, you have to go through the whole POI selection process again. This is a method that is not yet ready for the real world. It took me a good ten minutes to discover that the POI list didn't know about the particular version of the store that I thought it should know, I guess I didn't really need it, but then I'm not always in my own back yard. Garmin gives the address and direction of POIs before you commit to one.The map accuracy and POI list needs a lot of work.Only the main map display follows the day/night color scheme, the route map and browsable maps remain in their standard eye wateringly bright colors. A brightness control would be more useful than night colors, but to get to that you have to go to the PDA settings, not something I feel like doing whilst driving.At the end of November '05 Tomtom released Navigator version 5.21 for Windows Mobile 5. The behavior of the system has certainly changed. The most noticeable thing is that it now strongly prefers the shortest route in many situations. Unfortunately that means that it will now route me on surface streets rather than the adjacent interstate. For example Alameda to Emeryville can be achieved almost exclusively at 60mph+ on I880, I980, I580 and I80 and yet the new version chooses the surface streets at 25mph with lights every block. I suppose it can't be expected to know that the route it chooses goes through West Oakland which has more murders than most European countries. In the Mojave and Death Valley it often routed me down dirt roads when there was a decent highway nearby. Whether it's the map data or the routing, they need to know that a trail formed by a bulldozer driving through the desert isn't the same thing as a metaled road.I have contacted Tomtom customer support about the ludicrous average speeds, however they have not contacted me in a month, much less the 24 hours they promissed. Neither Tomtom not Teleatlas have given any sort of response to my eight map error reports, if I am going to all that trouble to accurately describe their errors the least they can do is acknowledge that they have received them, right now I don't know if they are dropping them in the round filling cabinet.After more research I have found many reports of Tele-Atlas inaccuracies (in the UK, for example, major towns missing and impossible directions at some of the bussiest interchanges in the country, like the M4-M25 near Heathrow airport, which may well be the first interchange many foreigners meet in the UK) and even major cities missing from the database.Compared to iNavigator 2.1.2 Europe: Tomtom update rates are faster, the maps are drawn better, the voice prompts are timed and spaced better. Tomtom shows more useful data than iNavigator, though still not near the standard of old Garmin dedicated units.  iNavigator Europe has some serious usability issues related to windows-style menus covering up essential controls like the map zoom and exit buttons. The zoom control on iNavigator is persistant, but not available as often and is very difficult to use whilst driving (on Tomtom the top corners zoom out and in, on iNavigator it's a tiny little control at the bottom center).  It may not be fair to compare the US Tomtom (Teleatlas) maps to the European iNavigator (Navtech) maps, but they are about comparable. Both have their issues but will still get you there in the end.On balance still a good product, however I am becoming concerned that the hype of the advertising campaigns isn't matched by world class technical teams. It took more than a month to answer the first support question with "sorry, no". But to be fair, most of it works well. And it is very pretty. Overall I haven't seen a better solution.Around two months after I asked some fairly pointed questions, on their web site, I just received three emails saying that I must update my questions to indicate that I still required support or they would close them if I did not respond in 48 hours. So I did. In each case I commented "yes I still want you to answer my question". That's an interesting technique for clearing your tech support backlog, but it does nothing for your customers. I'm starting to think that all they want is your money and they don't care whether they, or their product, does a good job.Despite my response they closed the calls 48 hours later. Not good.I did finally get some answers from support. You can buy the European maps on-line for a very reasonable price. They don't have any solution for the GPS receiver powering off when it loses bluetooth comms and they don't see it as an issue.I'm looking forward to a software upgrade which I hear should come out soon. I'll update this review when it does.
summary: Good product let down by maps, routing and support

reviewText: I bought this for my wife's new iPad Air.  I wanted what I hoped would be the best cover with the added nice option of having a keyboard...a lighted one at that!First off, the cover while being protective isn't particularly "grip-py" enough in it's tactile feel, it fact it can be slick.  Second, when she's using her iPad in bed prior to turning in for the evening it is next to impossible to get keep it from sliding out of the "propped-up" position.  This is a huge FATAL FLAW!  Any cover should have either a secure propped-up solution or a locking one.  This one has the worst I've ever seen as it barely will prop up and certainly will not remain so.Next, my wife has to press a button to "MATE" the BT keyboard with the iPad Air.  She'd rather just use the screen's keyboard she says because she forgets to join the keys and the screen.  Could be more my wife's forgetfulness, but whatever the reason the keyboard isn't a hit like I'd hoped it would be either.On the plus side, the materials used are quality even if the cover isn't the rubber-like tactile feel I, and apparently a lot of others, prefer.  The keyboard is beautiful all lit up and is somewhat amazing as it is possible to change the backlight color which while being non-critical is a very nice touch.  The keyboard itself is like a little brick - meaning it is built somewhat like a tank.  It has a bit of weight to it giving it an impression of being very solid indeed.  It is magnetic and will stay put until you forcibly detach it from the cover.  The battery life is excellent.  I do not even know exactly how long with light use it can go, but suffice to say I don't think we'll have any issues with the battery not lasting long-enough since my wife for whatever reason just prefers the on-screen keys.I would not buy this if I knew what I know after purchasing.  While maybe great for some users it has not been so for my wife and I wholeheartedly agree since it will not stay properly propped-up for love or money.  I actually hate the fact the back prop isn't worth a dime because this is a "deal killer" for us.  I'm going to buy my wife another cover simply put.  I feel dumb trying to "over-achieve" and get the best and what I thought was most advanced cover, out there.  This really backfired as a complete waste of money.  My daughter, who lives in Nashville, bought a simple pink rubber cover for her iPad Air at the Apple store.  She gave too much in a way for such a simple cover at $30...But, she didn't waste a dime because her cover does what it should.  It protects first and foremost, it will prop-up either on her lap while sitting down or laying in bed and it stays propped-up until you decide to un-prop it.  And, finally, it has the perfect tactile slightly sticky (doesn't act like dust mag though) feel whereby you won't accidently lose your grip and drop your iPad unless you're just have a bad moment.  These are the things a cover should do and the Kennsington Key Folio is a glorious costly failure as far as I'm concerned.

reviewText: I had high hopes for this to use as a repeater to extend the range of my wireless router, but it was not to be.While I have used other devices of this brand with great success, in this case, the unit was basically dead on arrival.I installed the PDF user manual from the included DVD and read through it. It is written such that the author clearly is not a native English speaker. In spite of this, it is very simple and straightforward. We are not talking rocket science here.Once this is plugged into an electrical outlet, and in range of your computer, you should be able to get to the homepage of the unit, by typing into your browser address bar the TP-Links address, which is: 192.168.0.254.Also, you should be able to ping this address and get a response. It's quite simple. The fact that I could neither ping this or get to the homepage, inspite of Windows Connection Troubleshooter seeing it, and giving a message that it wasn't responding, tells me this unit is defective.I plugged it in and the little blue light lit up to tell me it was indeed plugged in, but my computer was unable to use it.I pinged the device several times, and this was never pingable.Of course, I couldn't get to the tp-links homepage either, which is 192.168.0.254. This should be simple and straitforward. My Windows connection troubleshooter could see the device since it identified it, but it gave the message :TR-WR702N not responding.I conclude that the one I got is defective.I notice in some other one star reviews that people are making this simple device into something much more complicated than it is. If you plug this into an electrical outlet, and then type into your browsers address bar: 192.168.0.254, you should see the login to the homepage of this device. If you get that far and see the login page, your device is working, and you have an operating unit.If you simply want a repeater, in other words, to extend the range of your wireless router, simply plug this in. That's it. Check to see that it's working by trying to get to the login page of the device. That's what I intended to use this for, but it doesn't respond to requests from my computer.If you want a bridge, you would be creating a secondary local area connection. This would be used if you own, for instance, a restaurant, and want your guests to be able to use your internet connection without having access to your personal data.Here are the starting instructions, copied and pasted, from the user manual:"Preparation*Make sure the Main Router is on the Internet and you got the necessary Information of it as above.*Since the default mode of TL-WR700N/TL-WR702N is AP, the DHCP function on them is disabled by default. We have to manually assign an IP address as 192.168.0.X to the computer to match the default IP address (192.168.0.254) of the Repeater. Please click here for detailed instruction.*Connect the computer to the TL-WR700N/TL-WR702N with an Ethernet cable.Step1 Change the Working mode to Repeater.1. Set a static IP as 192.168.0.X to your computer. If you do not know how to change it, please click here.2. Open the Internet Explorer and type the IP address of the access point (Default is 192.168.0.254) into the address bar and then Press Enter:3. Type the username and password into the boxes of the login page, the default username and password are both admin, then press Enter:"As you can see, the wording could be better. And it's needlessly confusing. All you need to do is plug this device into an A/C outlet, and then type in the IP address of it's homepage. In other words, start from number 2. in the instructions.The DHCP server is disabled is AP (access point) mode. With a simple network you only want one DHCP server so the typical set up is one router which provides all services and multiple AP's, such as this device, to provide coverage.As far as this goes; "We have to manually assign an IP address as 192.168.0.X",Since I am using the same brand of router, a TP-Link, my IP address is in the 192.168.0.X configuration.  Your router brand will determine your configuration.  Belkin routers, for instance have the 192.168.2.1 configuration, and you can easily change this IPin your routers homepage.To summarize:1. I could not get to the login of the homepage of the device.2. I could not ping the device.3. Windows connection troubleshooter gave me the message: TR-WR702N not responding.I will update this if I get a replacement that works from the manufacturer.  I have contacted TP-Link and am waiting to hear back from them.Edit: Customer service has been super responsive, and I have received a replacement from them, so an update to this device will be forthcoming in the next few days.  Very impressed with customer service!UPDATE 4/20/2013Customer service has been excellent and I was shipped a replacement unit.The replacement unit does project a network that my computer can see, unlike the first unit.However I was never able to use it.  The password was not recognized.The default password for these units is "admin", and I got a message that it was the wrong password.  After trying this over a dozen times, and also trying the password that is printed on the bottom of the device, with the same result,  I have no idea how to log onto the network that this is broadcasting.When I get more time I will contact support and continue to try to get this to work for me.

I bought this because I was sick of burning CDs to listen to music in my car.  It's ONLY ok.I have a Mazda6, so the auxiliary input wasn't available for my car. Rather annoying...in fact (ding), that reminds me to call about that - it could just be my unit.  The third disappointment is that the scroll is SOOOOOO SLOOOOOWWW.  The main reason iPod is an MP3 player king is because it was the first MP3 player that had wickedly fast scrolling to go through your 9000 songs.  This unit, does not have wickedly fast scrolling.  The fourth, and disappointingly NOT final, disappointment is that the interface is NOT the same as on the iPod, as I was made to believe. The reason I purchased the Eye-Fi was to transfer short videos between my work area and my MacBook Pro.  I had hoped while I was setting up the next shot, the video would upload.The first frustration came from installing the software.  I absolutely do not trust that you must create an on-line account just to configure the card.  That seems absolutely pointless and just a way to collect personal information.The second was trying to connect to my WiFi.  It took 2 or 3 attempts (in which the installer appears to have locked up) in order to connect.The third was I did what the instructions said:  I put the card in my camera, snapped a still (and a 5 sec video), then went to get a cup of coffee.  When I came back, nothing had happened.Took me a while to realize I had to put my camcorder (Canon Vixia HFR 300) into Playback mode for the upload to start.  Which may not seem like a big issue.  However.  Turning off the camera or changing modes resets some of the manual settings.  So that means between each upload, I have to reset my camera  for the shot I am doing.  This is not at all any less hassle than moving the card back and forth between my computer and camera.Why 2 stars, when I admit my camera is part of the issue?1.  The needless email-based registration. (-1, should be -2)2.  The kludging of the software (looks to be a poorly written java program)  (-1)3.  Low value.  The card saves me no time, is half the size of my current SDs and almost twice the cost. (-1)
summary: No better than just moving the SD Card back and forth

I'm an in-ear headphone girl. I can't use the over-the-head giant headphones (like the nifty looking Beats Pro) for a long period of time, but I'm also oddly picky about how a pair of in-ear headphones fit. It shouldn't feel loose, like you have to keep pushing them in, and it shouldn't be so tight that you feel like you're pulling a rubber stopper out of the drain, if you know what I mean.This one actually fits even better than I expected them to. And, just because they're insanely cheap, doesn't mean their sound quality is utterly terrible either! There's a ton of reviews that go into some amazing detail about the sound quality, but what really stands out for me is their fit. It doesn't take much to stay in your ear, and they fit so well that they're my current go to when I go running. I couldn't help it; I also bought a few to keep as backup at the office cuz they're so cheap. So cheap!

Both the title and description are poor, making it unlikely to show up in common searches. I didn't know such thing existed until I stumbled upon it. Converts an external usb port into TWO internal ports.  Simply unplug the motherboard connection to one of your computer's unused usb ports (a front port for most people), and plug this to your motherboard to give your computer TWO internal usb ports.  Use one for a bluetooth adapter, and the other for a flash drive or wireless adapter. So now two usb devices are secure and out of view.What's with the description saying that it works with Microsoft Windows 98SE+ and Mac OS 8.6?  We know Windows is made by Microsoft, but thanks for reminding us.  Both those OS's are ANCIENT, and nobody uses them. Would be clearer to simply say that it requires no software, so works with all operating systems.
summary: very nifty, but nobody knows about it
