I don't know if I'm doing it ergonomically or not, but it feels a lot better to me.One complaint: the wheel is very difficult to click down on.  I use that middle click constantly in Firefox, and it's very irritating that it takes so much force to do so.

I have this brand of display protector on all of my cameras. It's just a standard purchase I make like an extra battery and a memory card. I have yet to have to replace any of them (though they do ship with two protectors and two cleaning kits to prep your screen). Unlike cheaper protectors they never bubble or fog. In fact it is almost impossible to tell they are on. I try not to baby my gear, but few things are as much of a bummer as a huge scratch across your LCD. This protector is virtually invisible and does a great job. Chances are there is one made specifically for the camera you own.
summary: The first purchase I make for all of my cameras

reviewText: Bought this drive to replace the original drive in my laptop. I didn't have any problems installing it and my BIOS found the drive without any issues. Was able to reload Windows XP Pro in a short period of time and have not had any problems with the drive itself.  It's quiet and speed is the same as the OEM my laptop came with.  My laptop runs almost non-stop and so far so good.
summary: Excellent drive, easy to install in Dell 1520 laptop

reviewText: This router works almost as good as the router my phone company provided with my internet. I dont use it anymore.

1st this came WITHOUT  the adapter for the 5c. A quick call to Amazon quickly fixed. Their customer service is awesome. However after the adapter arrived the unit would not recognize the phone and there was NO AUDIO so BACK IT GOES!!!!!
Again what can you say about memory cards.  They work great.  Formatted fine.  A nice storage upgrade for a good price.

I first saw this computer at Sam's Club (eventually where I bought it too) and was completely infatuated. This laptop delivers amazing value for the price. HP has definately brought their 'A' game on this model. There are a couple things you *need* to know before you buy this laptop.First, the model I bought advertised a 500 GB hard drive. This is true, however it is 2 x 250 GB hard drives. Not that big of a deal, but I cannot believe it is not listed as such.Second, the laptop comes preloaded with a ton of junk and is heavily integrated with Windows Live stuff. Messenger, Live toolbar, etc. It comes with a trial of Norton Internet Security and a trial of Office 2007. My advice: Get Norton off the computer ASAP and install another anti-virus product.Third, no operating system CD's come with the package. There is a "Recovery" partition that contains about 12 GB of stuff (not 100% sure what exactly is on there). I do know that when setting up the computer it tells you you should create recovery CD's. I went through the setup to create the discs and here's the kicker - they want 21 CD's or 3 DVD's to create the recovery discs. Talk about stupid.As of now, I have wiped the OS partition and loaded Windows 7 Beta. The driver recognition is fantastic on Windows 7 - both my wired and wireless ethernet drivers were install out-of-the-box.The look and feel of this model is gorgeous. The 17" HD screen is amazing and the whole laptop has this slick look and feel to it. The bronze color scheme really stands out.All in all, you cannot beat the price of this laptop. For what it comes with, a comparable model from another vendor would cost $600-700 more than what I bought mine for ($898 + tax).Last, this is just my opinion and should be taken as such. Please do yourself a favor and do not install XP on this. This laptop is too great to go back to XP. AERO does look nice and this laptop should be able to run anything you throw at it. Even a clean install of Vista should not give you any problems. While XP works great for most people, do not fight change and try to give Vista/7 a fair chance. Hell, even try the newest Ubuntu (I think 8.10) because that should look great on this too.
summary: It looks great, but make sure you did a little deeper

reviewText: I bought this to increase the warranty on a Corsair Voyager Air 1TB Wireless Mobile Storage With Ethernet (NAS), iOS that I bought for my GRANDSON on October 30, 2013. I wrote this vender 2X about getting a hard copy and got an unrelated reply to my question [the first time] and a request to call them [the second time]. When I tried to call them I got NO ANSWER! I won't consider buying from them again.

This speaker is cooler than I thought.  I bought it for my wife in "Purple Snowflake," she loves it, and so do I.  The sound is very good, volume is good enough as far as loudness, bass and treble.  The size is ideal, small and very light weight, like 5 candy bars stacked high. The Jawbone app is ok, another service to join, but I mainly use it for the EQ settings, which enhances the sound just barely.Hooking it up out of the box is super easy.  The voices and sound effects are pretty cool, when you power on/off, or battery strength and connectivity.  It has a nice kick when you hold it while playing music.  Little plastic stubs on the bottom help dampen vibration while upright.  Did I mention the purple is sweet looking, I highly recommend it!

Look, this lens will get you into the action (no problem focusing on your little soccer phenom), but at f/4 you have to compromise on either shutter speed or ISO.  So you may have to choose between motion blur or noise, neither of which is attractive.  Alternatively, you can use Photoshop (or equivalent)to correct these photos (ideally, your action shots should freeze your subject while blurring your background... harder to do at f4 than f2 or f2.8) by blurring the background after the fact.  That said, if you are on a budget, I can recommend the lens.  Just know in advance that you may have to compromise a bit on your shots and that you may be required to edit/retouch your photos to get the effect you are after.If you have a little more cash to spend, check out the relatively new Olympus Zuiko 18-180 lens.  This is one you can keep on your camera nearly all the time (f3.5-f6.3) It has just a slightly shorter range than the aforementioned Sigma.  I use it and I love it.  Really is a fantastic lens that didn't break my bank.

I really wanted this to work. It seemed to be the perfect solution for hotels that still don't have wifi internet (a lot of them unfortunately) since Android Tablets don't have ethernet ports. I followed directions to a T, my Asus Transformer is running ICS and my Samsung Tab is running Honeycomb, but neither worked. I noticed the unit got extremely hot in just a few minutes, so it may just have been a defective unit, but it simply did not function. Back to the drawing board I guess.OK, so it was my fault that this product didn't work, it was simply user error and it works fine with the Asus.  Besides showing my incompetence, however, the product deserves a 5 because of the way the company stands behind it.  It's a very inexpensive product and defects occur every so often in anything, regardless of cost.  What is really outstanding here is how much effort the seller made to fix the problem - even when he/she is obviously not making any profit when this amount of work has to be done.  Whenever you buy a product you're not just buying a "thing" you're also buying the company behind it and in this case I got a huge amount of value for my money.

Dismayed by the battery drain design flaw (read the other reviews), but sound quality is quite good and the unit packs well for travel.If only Phillips had fixed the battery drain problem before they released it.
summary: Great unit, but keep it plugged in...

reviewText: Based on the good feedback this flash has received I was looking forward to using it as a backup for my SB-800. I originally was going to purchase another SB-800 but was surprised to learn that they've  become the Rembrandt of flashes, going  for about $800 on eBay! Unfortunately, my Di622 must have escaped Nissin's QC. The TTL function was defective when used with my D300 and the flash  didn't work at all with my D200. I made sure I used  fully charged, metered batteries and swapped them between the Nissin & the SB-800. I wrote to Nissin thinking they might have a simple work-around, but have yet to receive a reply and i have a job coming up soon. (I was surprised to learn that Nissin charges for firmware updates and refers you to your local dealer (!) for more information.) So I bit the bullet and will soon be the proud owner of a SB-900*.Update: Turns out that Minox distributes Nissin, but this wasn't apparent on Nissin's website. Thus, corresponding with Nissin at first caused a delay in their response time. The terrific Minox rep offered to replace the strobe at no charge and was very helpful and forthcoming with information. Now that I know which manufacturers Minox represents and how good their customer service is, I'll check them out first next time.*WOW! Been using the SB-900 for just a day and am blown away by its performance/features.
summary: Defective out of the box, no help from Nissin, but Minox rep great.

reviewText: I bought this item in february 2013 for $95 after comparing many alternatives. During my 16 months of use, this product has proven itself as a very useful and durable piece of equipment, well worth the $95 I paid at the time.1- It is easy to mount on your plate and you can even mount it on top of an existing plate frame. (You don't need to have it on the bare plate as shown on picture). You may need a single drill to get the cord going into your trunk area but that does not look nasty in my car. I am not a techie so I got it installed in best buy (geek squad) to my boyo dashboard monitorBOYO VTM4301 4.3-Inch Rear View Monitorand paid $75 for that (after negotiating from the initial price of $100.) Like many users, mine is powered by a lateral cord coming from the rear transmission light so, it switches on as soon as I put my car in to reverse (approximately 2 seconds delay)2- It is a good quality camera. Over the time, this outside camera got exposed to a wide range of temperature extremes (-6F to +105 F) rain, snow, direct sunlight, and many more... No problems, what so ever. I can say that It had exceeded my expectations.3- Decent picture quality even in complete darkness. In my opinion this is not an artistic camera so expecting a professional HD or a movie quality would be unrealistic. This camera provides very clear images without distortion and is great to record details both in light and dark. You will never complain that you can not see something in dark like many others do with different cameras.4- It can move in the vertical direction and this helps adjusting the camera according to the position of your plate and the height of your car. However it is stiff enough not to move on its own unintentionally. For example, opening and shutting the trunk or car motion does not shift the angle.5-Thanks to its slim design, it does not attract lots of attention (hardly noticeable)  which makes it less likely to get stolen. I am not sure if anyone would bother stealing something that cheap but anyways.Cons:-The price as of june 2014 is $112 which is $17 more than what I bought it for. Amazon sometimes makes this type of  price fluctuations but I think it is not a fair increase and you may want to consider other vendors for better deals.-Although I am happy over all, I can still say it would be better if it had a little wider angle. But that increase would come with image distortion and might be irritating as well. My recommendation is that if you are backing up from a parking lot where two giant cars had been parked on both sides, you pay extra attention to the traffic behind while inching little by little.My conclusion is that this is a great camera that does the job pretty well. Just keep in mind this is not a replacement for checking the back with your own eyes no matter how good it is.
summary: great product but terrible price increase since I bought

reviewText: My HP pavilion dv7 will not fit in the bag (wasn't expecting it to because it's so huge but was optimistic). I can fit three 2" 3 ring binders in the bag snugly, with possibly a small text book. I think the bag is just about perfect for a college student, large main pockets and decent storage in the small one. The materials seem to be quality, same can be said about the zippers. I'm a little nit picky as far as what I do not like, but it's so insignificant I wont mention anything. Overall it would make a great travel/school pack.

It's the best one I have used so far in 40 plus years of photography.It moves when you need it to move. It stays when you need it to stay (especially hanging out an aircraft door or a speeding gunboat). It shoulders the load of my Nikon D800E,and Nikkor 80-200mm zoom. Dons & doffs easily, even with my big long guy attached. Allows easy arm clamping of your long lens in tight spots and crowds. No metal clips or swivels, so it plays nicely and safely in the bag, so you can load up quickly without worry. It does not tend to snarl up much like thinner straps.If you have lady like shoulders, so much the better. With $10K + or -, hanging around your neck This is the "strap insurance plan" you want. I have been using it for 4 months and no telltale marks on the straps where the slip thru the strap loops on the camera. Bitter end configuration is provided and cleans up your kit when shooting on the fly.Hands down the best strap money can buy if you shoot big, fast and expensive. it may seem like a lot of fat strap in the images but it handles like a dream all around. No fat strap worries in the bag to boot. This strap is reliably obtained on Amazon. Look for your choice color combo as well.
summary: Shoulders the Load, Handles like a dream. Best there is, period.

reviewText: great price and good product.  Every one was well machined and fits snugly.  Saves a lot of time dealing with rf TV cables when adjusting or moving video equipment.

I have had this shell on my MacBook for over a year now and it looks as good as day one.  Easy to snap on and off.  Pretty easy to keep looking sharp.  It smudges and grabs dust, but wipes clean with the included cloth.It has protected my computer from scratches, dings, dents like a champ.

Amazon doesn't accept a zero star rating, but that's all this product gets. The idea behind this product is good, but it's made so el-cheapo it's almost unusable.I found the cables long enough, although barely. They are 9 inches long. (That's 22.5 cm, more than the 16m on the product descriptor.)The real problem with this product is the external connector. It's barely usable. The connector has two small latches that are meant to lock the cable into place. They seem to be made out of foil. If utmost care is not used when inserting the external cable these latches bend inside the connector, making the connector unusable. Even if utmost care is used, these latches can bend in the same way. This WILL happen if you test the connector a few times before you put it in your computer. Once this happens, the connector is toast.The inside connector (the one that connects to your SATA port) is fine. It's not the one that gets reused, though.

Arrived in great shape. Looks good. Does it's job perfectly. I'm using it with the 3rd monitor on my PCs triple monitor display so that it's an all-purpose screen. I have the HDMI feed from the PC's GPU going in with DVR and PS3, then out to my 3rd PC monitor. I can easily switch from to any of them with the little remote, which is simple. It automatically switches when either the DVR or PS3 are activated, but can be switched back easily if needed. Great device.... wish it wasn't this expensive but it IS a 5 port, so that's good. I gave it 5 stars.
I bought this microsd card for Samsung Galaxy S2 Skyrocket (i727), and has worked well for well over a year now.  I highly recommend it.

I went ahead and gave this 5 stars because I couldn't cut one in half.  lol!Anyway the deal is that this cooling base is awesome, but there are a couple of improvements I'd like to see concerning the stand.First - I am amazed at how well this thing works - but it works best if the stand is up and if the cooling base is either on a desk or a hard surface while on your lap to allow for proper air circulation.  I use a small tray, but a hard cover book or even a clip board will work if they're the right size. The picture on the box shows someone  using it on their lap without the stand up but their legs are slightly apart - I wouldn't advise anyone to go by that picture because it still might not allow for proper ventilation for your machine, but that may depend on where the air vents on your machine are located.The way the cooling base's fan is situated, if the stand is not up then the air can't circulate too well and it not only uses up more energy trying to work (thus taxing your power source), but it won't work effectively, which I'm thinking could probably lead the thing to burn out sooner or later.  So make sure the stand is propped up and that the base is on a hard, flat surface.Next, the base's stand itself is a wee bit flimsy in that it easily falls down. I would suggest that the designer of this cooling base design some way that the stand can lock into place so that it doesn't keep collapsing - the slightest move can cause the durned thing to close up so if you're using it on your lap that can be a problem.  (Additionally, the designers of this product would do well to design one with a front stand as well - that also locks into place when it's open.)The second thing I don't like is that when I lift the stand up, it angles the laptop down a little too far for my own personal comfort level - so I compensate for that by propping the front end of the base up with one of my kids' wooden building blocks.  Since I place the unit on a small plastic tray that has edges on it, this works great.  The little tray I use is about 9 inches by 12 inches - and the little block I use gets propped against the sidewall of the tray so it doesn't slide out from underneath the laptop.One thing that's really cool (literally!) is how well the fan on this thing works, and it's so quiet you really can't hear it going unless you have the hearing capabilities of a dog, so there's really no noise interference to worry about.  But I've noticed that the tray I set my cooling stand on feels like it has been in the refrigerator after less than a minute of use - which I'm sure my laptop loves - but it can get cold on the legs.  Probably feels good in the summer time, though.  Anyway I put a small blanket or towel between me and the tray that I set this on when it's on my lap because even through my pants it begins to feel cold.This is a very efficient cooling base when used correctly - I highly recommend it, despite the issue with the stand.  You just can't beat this for the price, and if there is a re-design that fixes the stand issue for roughly the same price I paid for this one, I'll definitely purchase it.

I purchased this iPad stand to use in class for taking notes with a bluetooth apple keyboard. I currently have a smart cover on my iPad along with a Belkin snap shield case. The smart cover places the iPad at too steep of an incline for note taking, so I was looking for a stand that would fold flat easily and allow enough room for my iPad to fit without removing either or both of the covers. This stand certainly does the job! It is a simple wire stand coated in a black smooth rubber like plastic. It has three adjustable parts to allow for a near infinite range of angles, with screw/knobs on either end to tighten the stand into a specific angle. The rubberized material coating the wires keeps the stand quite stable and prevents it from sliding across the surface it rests upon. Some previous reviewers noted that the bottom support bar blocks the home key when the iPad is placed vertically in the stand, however, I am not experiencing that problem at all. I am not sure if the manufacturer adjusted the dimensions of the stand in response to this concern or if the new iPad simply has different dimensions, either way, it is not a problem with my stand. The stand is light weight and folds up perfectly flat, taking up minimal space in my school bag, which is perfect!Overall, you cannot beat the price and functionality of this stand. I considered other cheaper stands but finally decided on this one since it was one of the few inexpesive and highly reviewed stands that qualified for Amazon Prime. I cannot recommend this stand enough! A must have for any iPad owner.
summary: Great, no-frills  iPad stand for the price

reviewText: Sure, professionals and the exceptionally avid enthusiasts will want a camera with interchangeable lenses, more megapixels, and more features overall, but for its size and ease of use, the ELPH is one of the best digital cameras available.Photos taken at its highest resolution (1600 x 1200) and lowest compression rate can easily be blown up to 8"x10" in size, certainly adequate for the average photo enthusiast.  Automatic and manual controls allow for photography in most lighting situations.  The camera even can record short digital videos including sound, and the camera's user interface is customizable with new sound "themes" and a start-up image.Highly recommended accessories include a larger compact flash memory card or two; the 8-mb card included simply doesn't cut it unless you want to only take low-res pictures.  Buy a 128-MB card and store over 120 images at the highest resolution; they're cheap these days.  Secondly, you'll want a second or even third battery, as though the camera does include its own rechargeable pack, it will only last for 100 shots or so, and you won't want to waste time recharging when you're on the go.If you want a camera you can carry in your pocket that will give you instant results without having to send off film to the lab for development, you'll want this camera.  The ELPH is one of the best out there!
summary: Compact and Feature-Rich Camera for the Photo Enthusiast

reviewText: OK, For $10 you can't expect studio monitor quality.  But I've heard better from 2 juice cans and some string,  The frequency response is about 1khz to 6khz.  My cell phone sounds better.These are adequate  for the guy saying "You have mail", but beyond that, spend a few more $$.
Working fine and I would recomend them to all, in need of this item.The cable was right size and fits right, where it was being used.Robert

I have Cox cable and have been using their DCT6416 III DVR. This device has its flaws, but the biggest one was recording capacity. It only has a 160GB hard drive, which may have been good in the standard definition days, but is way too small in the high definition era. When I received a piece of mail from Cox saying we could add external storage, I started researching drives to do this. A forum I stumbled upon said for DVRs you don't want drives that have a power saving mode as the drive entering power saving mode can cause issues. This made me a little conflicted on deciding which drive to get so I'm glad they made a drive specifically for DVRs so I could be reasonably assured it would work with my DVR.Setup was very simple. I read some posts from a while back that talked about powering down this first, then plugging that, then turning this on, etc. I went with the simple approach thinking the software has been enhanced since then and should allow for a plug-and-play installation. Surprisingly, everything worked as I expected it to. I plugged in the drive's power, then plugged in the esata cable. I received a message on the DVR saying it detected a new drive and asked me to format it. After confirming, within a few seconds it said the drive was ready. I went to the DVR list and noticed that I was now using a small percentage of my DVR space, so everything seemed to be working without any reboots of anything. I don't notice any difference while accessing my DVR besides not having to worry about running out of space (finally)!The drive is extremely quiet. In fact, I can't even hear it over the noise of the DVR even when I'm right next to it. I've been feeling it every once and a while and I don't feel it getting hot at all.Overall, I'm extremely satisfied with this drive. It was designed to work with a DVR and it shows with how well the setup went and how it hasn't caused any issues with the DVR.
summary: Works great to make a limited DVR a better experience

reviewText: If the louvers on your car vents are thicker than most, the clips will not open wide enough for it to attach.  I have a 2003 Toyota Matrix and the clip actually broke off trying to slide it on.  The broken piece of the clip will forever be a part of the car as it fell inside the vent.  Buyer beware....this will not fit all vehicles...especially ones with larger than usual vent louvers.

Got this to replace my EF-S 17-55mm f/2.8, as I want to move to a full frame body someday.  It's a decent lens, good contrast, but doesn't seem as sharp as the Canon, although the MTF charts measure up.  The image stabilization feels weird through the viewfinder, it's kind of snappy compared to Canon's smooth motion, but it is effective.  Was deciding between this and the Canon 24-70mm f/2.8 II, and decided I wanted to keep the image stabilization of the EF-S and $1000.  If the new Canon lens would have had IS, I probably would have gone with that.

It's a big cheap  home NAS drive and does most of what I want it to.  It works well with my Windows and Mac computers.  But it isn't easy to use with my Linux machines, which is curious because the NAS server is a Linux machine.  I have not been able to get it to work with my Chromebook.  I'd give it a better rating if I hadn't spent so much time messing around with it.==================A few months later... downgrading from 2 to 1 star because it is so temperamental and unreliable.  I regret the purchase, and even more so, the time spent messing around with it.
By all means, get a class 10 card for 8 gig and up.  They format more quickly and some cameras run into buffering problems with lower speed cards. Good card.
Easy to mount. Took about an hour, with all the measuring and leveling and moving...Sits flat enough and articulates as expected.

My CSW i765 is 2+ years old and so far I have not experienced any outages or issues. It has been an average performer though, and there is not much that stands out in trying to do all things at once:- Excellent looks from the front, the CSW pictures are really good to look at- Video performance is so-so, you can use it in a pinch, but it is dated (no HDMI or Blu-Ray) as the best you can get is S-Video, not even component video.- Audio performs moderately well when the volume is kept low, but at slightly higher volume, it becomes apparent that the bass is artificially enhanced and the sound gets muddy- Flat remote belies common sense - the buttons do not have any tactile differences for commonly used ones, only their clustering and color distinguishes the functions. Ugh!- Radio reception is good, RDS works well- iPhone connection produces "not certified" warning; perhaps it has been changed recently but I have to click OK on mine to proceedI compared this with Mirage Ombivibe dock and Bose Sounddock. Both performed better in sound quality, as they kept the bass controlled and the vocals and mid-range clear. However, both Mirage and Bose lacked the controls for bass/treble.The CSW i765 was bought from CSW directly for 2 C-notes plus tax. I would hesitate to pay even that much today. I would not recommend it.
summary: i765 - still top of the line at CSW portables?

reviewText: Doesn't work with PS4, do not buy it if you need it for next-gen consoles. Worked fine for my PC though. But for whatever reason, it literally resets the PS4/flashes static on the screen. But when I got my Kinivo switch, it worked perfectly!Seller was fine and return was easy though!

Awesome product - I ordered this because my 4 port router was more than full. Plugged the switch into the router then into the wall and it was done. Very easy, no setups, no firmwares, simple. One thing you should be aware of (I'm not going to rate the products itself less because of this) is that the next generation models are out. It's the same thing but they are considerably smaller than the previous version. Amazon should really update there picture. I have this stacked on top of my Linksys wireless router and it does fit but it does not lay in the four corners and previous linksys products. Not a big deal and still looks fine but just a heads up. 5 Stars
summary: Plug N Play - No Setup Required

reviewText: The sound quality of these earbuds really blew me away. I admit that I'm pretty surprised to get this good sound from earbuds.I tested this with all sorts of music from classical to rap and in all genres the sound quality was deep, rich and full. I've had the opportunity to test many kinds of earbuds and headphones and I have to say that these earbuds hold their own even against more expensive full sized headphones. My only issue is that bass is somewhat strong, maybe even overpowering when playing bass heavy music but this issue is non-existent when playing music without heavy bass.Extras: 4 extra tips in different sizes, canvas carrying bag, Smartphone compatible with remote and mic, cord clip, and canvas covered cord which should help with tangles.Fit: The tips that it came with were a little big but I switched it with one of the extras and it was a perfect fit. The buds themselves have an asymmetrical design so it was easy to tell which one was left and which was right, besides which the cord clip is on the left cord. I also like the fact that the buds have a flat exterior so it was easy to push them into the ears.Overall: Very, very good sound. This is the best quality sound coming out of a set of earbuds I have ever tested. Until I come across a better set of earbuds, at which time I'll update this review, I give this my highest recommendation.

Exactly what they say. Decent (not especially good) sound response, pretty comfy fit, lightweight, and I've had no problems with durability despite accidentally yanking the cord, wrapping them every time, and throwing these in my black hole of a backpack for days on end. I had an old pair like this that I felt the same about, and got these because they looked the same (I'm now almost positive they were). I thought my old ones had single wire on one side though, and that would be nice to see on these.I listen to music and lectures with these, and they fit the bill just fine. I listen to a ton of genres and put these guys to the test with all of them - no issues. Also, the couple reviews about all the cords snapping off I just don't believe. Like I say, I have been quite rough with the cord with no issues, crackling, etc after several months of continuous use.

There isn't much to say about this one, but if you're looking for an inexpensive 4-port USB2 hub go ahead and buy this one.I've been using it pretty solidly for 6-8 months now and haven't had any issues with it. It's cheap, it works well, and I have had no problems with powered or un-powered devices.
summary: Need a cheap USB 4 port hub? This one works well

reviewText: I had cheaper splitters in the past. I can't say anything regarding signal quality but when the cheap gold colored splitter I purchased broke I decided to pay a little extra hoping this would have better construction. This splitter is built better than the other cheap splitters I've used in the past and has been holding up for a while now. They're not much more than the cheaper splitters either which make them a great value.I use this to split the signal from my antenna for over the air ATSC tv signals to feed 2 tuner cards and my tv's digital tuner. works great.
Good hub, I've already filled it (using it as a docking station for my Surface Pro).  USB 3.0 is a good touch, my drive is working fine.  Ports are spaced nicely to allow everything to plug in.

First I am not a IT professional but I am not a newbie either and this SBG6580 has the worst installation instructions I have ever seen. I spent a couple of hours trying to guess how to install all my devices and put one laptop on the 5 mhz channel. I finally had to call Motorola and the first thing they wanted was a credit card with a minimum of $30.00 just to start. To put a specific device on the 5 mhz channel it was even more money because that was a new issue.Once I got everything hooked up I found the range was very disappointing and then after about an hour my speed went from 32 mbps down to 10 mbps. I rebooted and it was back to 32 and an hour later back to 10 and it did it again and again. To make sure it was not the cable I put the old 2.0 router back on which was not as fast along with a Medialink Wireless N router and it worked just fine with no sharp drop-off in speed. This unit is being sent back today.With that said I still think Motorola makes great products but if you want the fastest speeds out there you are going to have to get separate components. I am ordering the Motorola SB6121 3.0 modem with the Linksys Ev200 ( V2 ) router which is expensive but has the best speeds, best range, most features out there.I hope Motorola takes note and comes up with some easy installation software or at minimum some decent instructions for us average folks in the future.

Saw these for half off list at BB on Black Friday. I could not pass them up whatsoever. Total impulse buy, but I don't regret it! The actual pair I got was the last in stock at my local BB store. They were "open item" which imo means "free extra discount" because they were new and came with everything the factory sends with them, even little rubber feet you can stick on the bottom. They were in perfect, flawless condition. Got these for $40 when they list for so much more. Now, I never really have been interested in Polk because I feel they're too overpriced for what they are. I mean, this pair is $100 and I feel that's not worth it for what they are. Now I do have very high standards as I am an audiophile and audio engineer, but I do have a rather limited budget. So I really have mastered the price to performance ratio when I buy equipment. So I suppose for someone who doesn't have any quality speakers at all, these could be worth list price, just not to me. But this review isn't about price, so it's really up tp the individual buyer.Anyways, on to the speakers themselves... Immediately hooked them up to the HT when I got home. I'm using a Pioneer 521, 522? I don't remember off hand because I get confused as to what I have vs what the newest product is. It's Pioneer's standard AV receiver line which I think is the absolute best you could buy for the price. I would always go Pioneer for AV receivers, actually I would go HK first, but that's a whole different pricing niche. So I put on some Pink Floyd Dark Side cause I always use that CD for reference when working with audio since that album is sonically rich and detailed. I noticed, and even expected, the highs were a little flatter and more mellow than I am used to. This is probably because my stereo set up has JBL with titanium dome tweeters while these have silk soft dome. They even advertise this exact effect. And overall the sound sounded a little flat in all ranges. I personally did not like it and it turned me off from these speakers at first. But as I begin to listen and listen, I got used to the subtle change and really just judged these speakers as themselves, not comparing them to others. Which I think is a big mistake people do. They love to compare everything they buy to they're favorite set which is really unfair. They started to sound nice and clean. The highs presented themselves well but were not harsh, the mids cleared up a bit. Still a little muddy though. The bass was tight and accurate, but not deep (this is expected though and not a complaint). I started to tinker with an EQ and just some subtle touches will really bring these babies to life. So if you're using them for stereo mains, you might want to invest in a good EQ or tinker with your source if it has one. I think the speakers just need a good break in. I think that will add more definition to the sound and the flatness will slowly disappear. Definitely recommend a burn in period for these before any real listening.These have been permanently delegated to the job of surround speakers as I intended them to be. They are really good in this position. They have brought out so much more definition to the surround sound of HD TV and movies. I truly am immersed in the sounds of what I am watching now. These are the perfect surround speakers.So overall, they're good speakers. Might be worth list price for the first time buyer, but really try to get them on sale. Give em burn in time, and don't expect something these are not capable of doing. Use them as intended. They work best as surrounds, but can be good for small hifi applications at home or office. If you follow those things, you will be very happy with these speakers. Definitely recommended.*One really, really nagging thing though. Since it is Polk and they are pricy, I fully expected them to have crossovers. But I could find no information showing that they were. They really sound like they are, but I need concrete proof they are. I don't want to open up my brand new speakers just to check if they have xovers. So if anyone knows, please leave a comment with your proof. And a warning to any potential buyers, do some research and find out if they have xovers. Cause if not, they are worthless and definitely should not buy.
summary: Superb as Surrounds, Decent as Mains/Fronts

reviewText: When people get super worked up over their UV filters I get upset, it's most likely only their to protect your lens and there is no reason to over think it. If you buy a cheapo filter, expect flare and chromatic aberration. CMOS sensors are sensitive to UV and often use it to determine WB and color profiles, so filtering it out will have some effect in that regard. Shooting RAW and adjusting in post is a better option anyway. This problem will exist wether you buy a $150 cokin, or a $20 tiffen.B+W on the other hand are a good, mid-range price filter with low aberration, and a small enough profile on the lens. In Macro work, I take the filter off, simply because their is no need for it, and it helps my d7000 focus. Regardless of B+W's large thread ring profile, the glass is quite thin, and produced minimal flare. Theyre easy to clean and a great touch of protection for your lens.Check out their X-Pro line as well, especially if you shoot outdoors a lot.
summary: Does what youd expect, nothing else

reviewText: I have owned this drive for a couple of months.  I bought it to use as tablespace for an Oracle database that I have on a laptop.  I wasn't sure what to expect, but external storage was my only option so I opted for the USB 3.0 since my laptop has a 3.0 port.  The drive is beautiful, quiet, reliable, and pretty fast for an external solution.  I have not seen any cons to mention in my short, but industrial use of the drive.  I would buy it again - in fact, I think I will to use as a backup.

reviewerName: Kilgore Gagarin "Those who believe in telekin...
reviewText: Pros:* Keyboard and key size* Sharp looking - matches iPad Air and looks like an Apple product which it isn't* iPad works in vertical and horizontal positions* Automatic on/off when mounting/removingCons:* Not really useful as a protective case* Pretty much useful only while sitting at a desk or tableThis is the second Belkin iPad keyboard I've tested (the other was aBelkin QODE Slim Style Keyboard and Case for iPad Air (Purple))and they both have similar strengths and weaknesses. The biggest strength is that as a keyboard, this is outstanding. I have no problem typing up large amounts of text and back spacing and deleting, etc. It is smaller than a full size keyboard, but it just didn't have that crowded feel I've felt on others. It also looks beautiful and matches the iPad air as if it were an original Apple product.The biggest weakness (both keyboards) is they're not really very good as protective cases. This specific keyboard's magnets are a bit on the weak side (I wouldn't trust them). If you think of this as more of a portable keyboard that can be attached and ported with your iPad, and you'll do fine. NOT very useable on a lap (so using in the car without something like theAutoExec Wheelmate Steering Wheel Attachable Work Surface Trayis not recommended). With that context, this is an outstanding keyboard.Summary: Works great, beautiful, but not very protective.
summary: Great keyboard, not great as a case

reviewText: Bearing Type: BallNo, this is just a sleeve bearing fan.  Contact the manufacturer and ask them.  In fact it is printed right on the box!  "SLEEVE BEARING".  The problem is that I purchased this fan specifically to be mounted in a horizontal position.  So what is the big deal you ask?  Sleeve bearing fans are not designed to be run horizontally!  They will quickly wear out and get noisy if mounted horizontally.  Use your favorite search engine to look up the details.  Basically ball bearing fans last longer and can be mounted horizontally without any problem.I learned this the hard way by mounting sleeve bearing fans horizontally.  They would become loud and die prematurely even though the same brand fan was mounted vertically in the same case and was still running just fine.However this is an excellent sleeve bearing fan and will work just fine in the vertical position which it was designed for.
summary: Despite Amazon's description this is NOT a "ball bearing" fan

reviewText: If you have a tablet and you need a small portable keyboard, the SHARKK Backlit Wireless Bluetooth 3.0 Ultra-Slim Illuminated keyboard is the way to go.  It is compatible with a PC or Windows Phone, iOS (iPad, iPhone), and Android OS (I've used it on my Kindle Fire HD).  The keyboard is extremely lightweight.  There is a supplied USB cable, but it is only for charging the battery.  And speaking of battery, while I don't know if the extremely long life promised in the description is accurate, I can say that the battery charges quickly, I tend to only turn the unit on when I need it, and thus far it has worked just fine for long bouts of me having to take notes at meetings.The keys can map to whatever device you are working on just by holding the 'Function' key and tapping the appropriate key in the upper-right-hand corner (the keys say, "for iOS", "for Droid", and "for Windows").  I don't always remember to do this, and I haven't really had any problems:  I'm guessing that pressing the button drives how advanced key combinations work.I bought this also because it has a backlight and I find that an extremely useful feature.  It's not a very strong light, but it does glow a little bit when you're in a dim or dark room.For the price, I'm very happy with this keyboard.  It isn't a marvelous joy to type on like my full-sized PC keyboards, but it gets the job done very well.

I acquired one of these to share music with my companion on a recent trip, and it worked perfectly. The Monster splitter connects to the MP3 player's regular headphone jack, and two male headphone connectors go on the split ends. It fits any standard headphone jack and doesn't affect sound quality at all -- this still depends on how good the MP3 player and the headphones are. What I particularly like about the Monster is that it has independent volume controls for each headphone, a little dial set flush to each side of the splitter. Otherwise, we'd have a problem: since I like my music louder than my partner, splitting the sound and not the relationship is the way to go!

----------(The item I am reviewing is Targus PAUK10U USB Keypad)----------This doesn't work with a mac unless...Do exactly as I say and it will work fine:1. When your Targus keypad is disconnected press and hold the Num Lock button.2. Connect your Targus Keypad USB cable to your mac USB port (not a hub) while still pressing and holding the Num Lock key.3. When the Num Lock green LED light goes on, wait for exactly at least three seconds (count 1, 2, 3) then release the Num Lock Key.4. Now it shouldn't Beep and it will work fine in programs like Excel.-----------I am typing a bunch of numbers on it as a proof below:123456789 0 000 . / * - +It works smoothly.-----------I gave it three stars only for being such a hassle to use on macs when any stupid USB keyboard would just work.I have a MacBook (latest intel black model) running mac OS X 10.5.6-----------I hope that was helpful.
summary: Yes! I made it work with my Mac and here is how

reviewText: I am using a 2012 Mac Mini. It has limited USB ports available and I was tired of taking one of them up with a Logitech dongle. So I replaced my Logitech keyboard and mouse with bluetooth options. The pros of this keyboard are: 1) It has good key spacing for people with large hands like mine. 2) It has a number pad; unlike the Apple Keyboard. 3) It is fashionable and goes well with Apple's signature aluminum and white styling. 4) It pairs very easily to Mac products. 5) It allows for up to three connections so that you can use it with multiple products. For those who are used to more robust keyboards, it may take you some time to get used to the feel of the keys or the flatness of the keyboard itself. It is not as comfortable to type on as the Logitech keyboard I replaced it with. However given that I accomplished the task of freeing up my USB ports, I am pleased with the trade-offs.
summary: Not my favorite keyboard, but can't beat it for the price.

reviewText: I bought these headphones for use on my commute by ferry boat to work during the week.  I wear them for about 2 hours each day.  I was initially worried that they'd be uncomfortable on my ears since my other headphones are the around-the-ear (circumaural) type.  I find them perfectly fine for wearing a couple hours each day.The noise cancellation works very well.  It cuts out the engine noise on the ferry very well and does not negatively affect the sound quality.  I like that the noise cancellation runs about about 50 hours on a single AAA battery, and that the headphones work even when the battery is dead.  On one occasion I forgot to turn the power off and found the battery drained the next day; it was nice to know that I could continue to use the headphones until I got home.Finally, I really like how compact and portable they are.  I store the headphones in the supplied carrying case inside my bag while riding my bike to/from the ferry.  It's great to know that they won't get damaged while in my bag.  They do look fragile, but with a little common sense and care they'll last a long time.
summary: Skeptical at first, but now I love them

I just bought an older used TV/Monitor to connect an Xbox 360 through HDMI. The display only has speaker level audio outputs so I used this device to route the audio to my 2.1 computer speakers instead of buying a separate HDMI receiver or the Xbox audio adapter (RCA + digital) or even a digital to RCA adapter (I'm using an Xbox slim).I believe they reversed left and right channels (I need to verify this, can't really remember) but a quick visit to youtube for a stereo test on the Xbox cleared that up.I've yet to balance the outputs with a multimeter so I instead just adjusted the balance on my TV. There seems to be an audible buzz in my speakers when the TV is off, but I'm not 100% sure that's the converter's fault. I just wish the dials for the output levels were easier to access but I suppose this device is meant to be mounted for a car stereo setup and never touched again til the configuration is changed.Other than that, you can't complain much at this price point. The shiny plastic definitely makes it feel cheap. They should've just gone for a more flat color instead. I mean, who wants fake chrome anyway? Oh wait, nevermind don't answer that...EDIT: So this thing has started to cut out and upon closer inspection, the pots for the gains are non-existent. I cracked it open and I can now see that there are contacts that need to be soldered in order to work. At the moment it's rigged up with a bent staple to keep contact since one channel refuses to stay on. If it fails one more time, I may just end up buying an HDMI receiver or at least a  better line level adapter. Unfortunately I'll have to drop it down to two stars as it is barely usable right now.
summary: Does the job but feels and looks cheap. EDIT: it's now falling apart

Been browsing around for a surveillance security system, not too expensive, not to cheap.  Coudn't settle on one system as I still want to expand my research to as many samples until I get comfy with which one I want.  Then I happen to be at Sam's Club one day and I saw this Uniden Guardian G766.  Checked the reviews on amazon and found several happy customers and almost equally unhappy customers. What the heck, I'll just pick it up and pretend that the unhappy customers didn't exist.  Paid $349 plus tax.  Connectivity from camera to main unit is awesome. On one camera, its separated by 3 walls and 70-80 feet, no problems, image quality is great. The other camera is closer and just one wall separates.  After I hard-wire the main unit to the router using the included ethernet cable, it forever attempts to connect to the internet. This is where the word "frustration" is redefined at its best. It never connected to the internet except for a couple minutes when I power it down and power it back up which it connects to the internet for a couple of minutes and the connection drops and the error message will say "connecting to the internet, please wait". Yeah, I wait 2, 3 or 4 days and it never connected to the internet. I'm interested in being able to check these cameras on my iphone when I'm away from home since I work nights.  2 weeks later, I started to gather the packaging so I can re-package the unit and return it to Sam's Club. Image quality is great, everything else is a POS.  Took a nap, when I woke up, I saw the globe icon signifying "connected to the internet" (without the running dots).  Wallah!! Checked my PC and ran the OCX software on my Windows 7 starter netbook and yes!!! there's my surveillance camera, can now be seen on the internet.  Ran the iphone app and BINGO!!!  While I was on the freeway on my way to work, I can check the cameras via my iPhone on the go.  Great!! I immediately planned on writing a review on this unit regarding my "natural high" experience with how great this unit is.  As soon as got home from work in the morning, I turned the unit off to see if I can turn it back on with no problems.  Pressed the "connect to the internet" button and it's been trying to connect to the internet for more than 36 hours now.  Sam's Club here's your Uniden Guardian G766 and give me my money back.  And by the way, how come you don't see G766 model on the Uniden's website?  It only mentions G755.  If you can make this unit connect to the internet using the included ethernet cable, please share it.  Otherwise, this unit is a $350 piece of toy. Find something else. Unless you just want an in-house surveillance camera. Then this is good enough.Update 3/6/13:  I have found the trick (or the right way) to keep the main unit connected to the internet.  So, you can now see 4 stars on my review. I had it with 3 stars on my initial review based on being difficult to connect to the internet. Now that I'm able to see the cameras on my iPad and iPhone, I think this unit is PROBABLY one of the best in this price range. I say probably because I havent tried other units and I'm just basing my wild comparison on negative reviews of others in this price range.  Very good connection between unit and camera (80 feet with 3 walls in between, gives me 1 bar on the signal scale), picture quality is awesome even with 1 bar. I am now recommending this Uniden Guardian G755/G766 to anyone looking for a quality surveillance unit within this price range.  I can also view the cameras with my HP Netbook using Windows 7 starter. I have not yet enabled the video recording mode because there are a couple of palm tree leaves slightly in front of my Camera #1 and I dont want the system to record the video triggered by the constant moving of these leaves. However, I was able to snap a sample picture of my daughter as she was approaching the main door (from the outside) where my Cam #1 is mounted. I told her to stop for a moment so I can take a picture and check the image quality (this was taken at night, and my front door is lighted with a 75 watt incandescent bulb). Picture quality is better than I expected. The reason I'm not giving 5 stars is because the add on cameras I think are a little expensive. I just purchased one camera yesterday directly from Uniden (amazon is out of stock) and it costs $129 plus tax and shipping, comes to $153. I paid $349 plus tax @ Sam's Club, main unit and 2 cameras for mine. The camera is well built, metal casing and feels heavy & strong but the price could be lower.Update 3/7/13:  I'm really frustrated now. While continuing to tweak my Uniden Guardian to connect to the internet, I was looking at the monitor when I saw the Fedex guy drop off a box. Yes, its my third camera which I paid $153. Wasnt excited since its useless for now. Cant connect to the internet.  Box still unopened as I write this update. An hour later, I went to Frys a mile away from my house to buy something for my home theater. Stopped by the security cameras section to see what they have. Well, I saw a heartbreaker: they have the Uniden Guardian G766 (same as mine) for $344 plus tax. No big deal, $5 cheaper from what I paid at Sam's Club. But when I looked at the box next to it, its the GC45 camera, same as the one I just got, price is $110!!! All  have long enough cables (and it includes cables to merge two fans into one connection to save motherboard real estate for even more fans) to manage the cables with no issue.This thing is incredibly spacious as well. Tons of left over room for cables and adequately sits the power supply and motherboard with no problems. Also has docks for Hard Drives and Optical drives for easy installation. Also has a USB 3.0 front panel with an eSATA port, 4 USB ports, microphone, Firewire 400 and speaker ports. Also has a neat little slide panel that conceals and covers the power/reset/LED toggle buttons.This thing is awesome. And heavy. And massive. I am in love with it.

My wife tends to ride me a bit about my expensive tastes in relatively high-end audio equipment.  She thought her $20 GE radio was plenty adequate, even for an NPR junkie like herself.  Seeing that the Kloss Model One is the radio sold by NPR at its website store, I gave her one as a gift.  Now she claims that the prospect of waking up to its warm, rich sound is enough to make her look forward to getting up in the morning.  In fact, she's beginning to agitate for two more identical radios for additional rooms in the house.My own feelings about the radio are a bit more toned down but positive.  In most similar radios "stereo" is an exuse to use cheap speakers. This monaural unit, on the other hand, features one carefully tuned and balanced speaker (the weight of the magnet itself testifies to its superior quality), reminding some of us that the "improvement" of stereo over monaural "hi fi" can be illusory at best.  The sound is full, rich, and complete over the entire sonic spectrum.  Moreover, the absence of tone controls encourages the listener to trust the engineers' judgment rather than waste time on equalizer switches. (I'll confess that personally I miss the ability to increase the treble and roll back the bass, which is too strong even without the gratuitous add-on "subwoofer.")  Finally, the tuning knob is the smoothest and most accurate, not to mention the most finger friendly, that I've used.Pure functionality, elegant simplicity, and noticeable attention to quality (especially the wood cabinet) make this the one to own.  Add a CD player, and you have a mini-component system built around a sensitive, responsive tuner and carefully tuned speaker.  Add another speaker, and you've got a stereo system (a supplement that, according to Consumers' Reports, makes this a better-sounding radio than the Bose, Boston Acoustics, or Cambridge competitors)--but at the expense of some of the compactness and economy which is undeniably a big part of this item's understated appeal.

I bought this to supplement my main sound system, which is all analog.  I really wanted to use my iPod as a music source, but wanted to get good sound.  This iPod dock/DAC is just the ticket.  I hooked it up easily, after reading the little booklet, and it sounds very, very good.  The provided RCA cables went right into the "to be used later, if ever" box, and Monster cables were used.The sound is exemplary, very detailed and open.  With more and more of us using iPod/MP3 devices, the Teac engineers used quality all the way through, both in build and design.  In short, as an experienced listener, I can recommend this to those who wish to use the iPod as a source of good sounding music.  The cost benefit analysis tilts strongly in favor the Teac.  Good sound, at a fair price.  Two thumbs up, high!
summary: A great performer and a bargain!!!!

I love these cases and have bought many of them. The only trouble I have run into is that the USB 3.0 cable doesn't plug in to my complete satisfaction, so I have a tendency to push a little too much on it, and I've pushed the plug in too far and bent it. I had to open the case up and bend the port back down carefully and it seems to be fine. I'm careful with it now, and just let the plug hang out a little like it needs to. It never falls out or comes unplugged, but it's not as secure as my WD passport drives.+--------------------After using this enclosure for some time I am back to add to this review. The USB port broke off inside. I took the case apart and can see that the port was soldered to the board in a way that doesn't give it much strength. I'm worried about the other drives I've put into these enclosures now. I decided to try the Inateck brand and so far I prefer it because the one I ordered uses a USB Standard Type-A plug on both ends of the cable. I don't think I'll ever buy another enclosure with this style of USB port (USB 3.0 Micro-B Plug). In the end, this enclosure was neat but not durable enough.
summary: Don't push the cable in too hard, usb port broke off inside

reviewText: These really are magical, and well worth every penny. When I connected them from my CD player to my amp, I was able to play back an actual performance of Bach's St Matthew's Passion (the original version from 1727), conducted by Bach himself. This proves, btw, that Bach did, indeed, use a one-voice-per-part approach.Later the same day, I put on a Beethoven CD and heard Ludwig himself playing sketches from the Hammerklavier in early 1818.But if you think it's qualities are limited to classical music, I tried a Grateful Dead album, and got Pigpen riffing on Lovelight from back in 1969; Bill Evens playing at the Village Vanguard, but not the well-known 1961 recording, but a later show in 1963. And as a final test, I listened to Jimi Hendrix playing acoustic guitar when he was 11.Of course, all of this has a price, and only the most discerning stereo lover would be willing to pay for it. But the magic is there, and no other cable offers such realism as this.

I'm sure the price on these will vary a bit but at the time of this post it was well under $10.  For all of those complaining about how stiff they are or how hard they are to clamp on, let's get something clear...these are HEAVY cables and if you fold metal cables they kink the performance drops.  The casing on these things are fantastic for protecting and shielding the heavy gauge cable inside and the grip (although a bit excessive at first) is needed...and welcomed if you've ever had one of 100 cables in the back of your system pop off and not have a clue where it came from.  How often are you unplugging these things anyway?  Plug them in once and be done.  When you're buying monster your buying heavy cables and shielding and solid connections..that's the point IMO.And don't expect to use the 4ft. cable on components 4 feet apart..that's not how to gauge the length you need.  I have no problem bending these cables a full 180 degrees for connecting stacked components, but they are stacked right on top of one another..and my components on the rack exceed no more than 2 feet in total height.  If you're connecting devices 3 feet or more apart and the plugs are pointed the same direction you should get the 8 footer.I now own 2 sets of these and I'm tempted to buy more but I suspect I won't need too many more with the shift to video sources using HDMI cables.  If you need a short component run for your amp, or component switch...look no further.
summary: Fantastic cables at a fantastic price.

Usually, I pay close attention to the reviews on Amazon, even if I'm shopping at a local brick and motar store. In this case, I needed a new blu-ray player and I saw this at Wal-Mart. It cost about $15 more, but I needed the player. I took out my smart phone, scanned the UPC symbol on the Amazon app and these reviews popped up. Now, as always, some people are very pleased with the player because they were able to get the major selling point, WIFi and associated apps, to work. And I'm sure it's a great player WHEN those features work.I have too many connected devices (besides tablets and laptops) to have someone say "it's your router". I just connected a Sharp Aquos LED HDTV with no problems. But this player would not connect completely. I followed the instructions, and would get a message that a connection to my LAN was successful, but when I went to start an app (Amazon and Netflix) I would get a message that I needed to connect to the Internet! I finally dove into the menus and found that it was trying, unsuccessfully, to acquire an IP address. The fix suggested by Vizio? Go to static IP address rather than dynamic. FAIL! I moved the player NEXT to router and still could not get a connection.My suggestion ... Pass on this player. As much as I love Amazon, I'm glad I bought it locally as I am boxing it up and returning ASAP. The negative reviews are consistent, poor or non-existent WiFi connectivity.
summary: If the WiFi doesn't work, I don't care about the player

reviewText: I purchased the TS20 from Amazon.com 2 days before my trip to Mexico.  Above water, the camera is everything expected (lightweight, stunning photos, easy navigation, slim profile, etc... If this was not advertised as a waterproof camera, I would have given it 4 stars... underwater is another story.  Before I get into what I happened, just know that I studied the user manual thoroughly before I used it in the water.The first day of the trip was completely away from the water.  Took some token pictures of mountains, the ocean, etc, etc; routine stuff.  The second day of my trip I went snorkeling and this is where the trouble began.  I took the camera snorkeling and captured some great pictures and video underwater.  Even in water the view finder provided clear images.  After about 30 minutes or so in the water, I swam back to the boat and began to clean the camera;  The manual provides basic cleaning instructions and I followed them to a tee.... about 45 minutes after I got onto the boat, I took the camera out to take some more pictures.  The camera came on, but all the buttons ceased to work.  I could not zoom in, use the menu or use any of the camera's functions after that.  I was relieved to find all my images/video were saved onto the SD card, but the camera was still inoperable, which is really a shame because the underwater shots came out great.Currently I am in the process of sending the camera back to Panasonic to see if they can do anything under the warranty... best case scenario they fix the camera and I use it only for above water photos... worst case scenario, I purchased a $135 paper weight...UPDATE 12/1/2012:I received a replacement camera late last week. In the notice included with the packaging, Panasonic stated the camera was either re-manufactured or brand new. From the looks of the packaging it appears to be a brand new camera.  Either way, the camera is in full working order and has been designated as my main "out of water" camera.  FYI... They also sent me an entire new set of cables, battery, charger, etc.. which was good because I left the original charger back in Mexico.About the process:I had to call and get a authorization code, send in the camera with a letter stating what happened and wait about 3-4 weeks.  Never received a call regarding the status, the replacement just showed up on my doorstep when I got home from work.

reviewText: This adapter is supposedly compatible with wired headsets connected to BlackBerry phones.  It did not work with my BlackBerry Flip 8220.  The mike worked OK but there was no sound in the earpiece.  I did verify there was no problem with either the phone or headset by connecting them together with a genuine BlackBerry headset adapter -- the headset worked fine, both mike and earpiece.  I believe this adapter is wired incorrectly, ie. to the wrong plug ring, and that's why my headset wasn't getting any sound.  It's possible that this adapter was only designed to connect headphones/earphones to the BlackBerry and not a full microphone/earphone headset.  If so, the product description needs to be changed to make this clear.  A "headset" with respect to a cell phone generally means a combined mike and earphones unit, not just the earpieces.
summary: Adapter is Wired Incorrectly for Mike/Earpiece Headset

I bought these Memorex paper sleeves (box of 100) a number of years ago because I was tired of jewel cases that either were too bulky, too flimsy, or fell apart.I've had CDs and DVDs in these sleeves for over 5 years now, and they have not ripped, yellowed, or separated.  The paper is a good sturdy weight, same as regular copy/printer paper.  The window is clear gloss plastic, and it's large enough to see most labels without problem.  I use them in my vehicle to keep CDs for the stereo - they take up far less space than jewel cases which allows me to keep more CDs in the console.  At my desk, I use them for data/backup discs and again, they take up way less space than jewel cases, let alone those huge retail packages some software discs use.Ready to buy another box of 100, and I won't even consider another brand.  You can pay less for others, but I want something better than near-tissue paper, and these sleeves have proven their value with me already.

reviewText: The speaker worked for a few months, then the audio jack starts to have problems.  I got these on sale, but it's not worth it if it break so easily.Edit:I realize my original review did not tell others much about the speaker. So after testing the speaker again, I found out what cause the speaker to have no sounds. The original audio cable broke. I used a male to male audio cable and plug it into the front port of the speaker instead of using the original cable and it worked again. Good thing this speaker offer a audio in port instead of the usual headphone port at the front.I am no audiophile, but his speaker does have great sounds. So I changed my original 1 star review to 3 star. If only Altec Lansing would use a better quality cable, this would have been great.

I was very pleased with these earphones, -the sound quality approached the Ultimate Ears Pro 5's I had used for three years previously and they were much less expensive.  However, each earpiece has a screen inside and after six months the screens are clogged.  I know that is gross but it's true.  Aside from scraping, which doesn't clear the screens, there's no way to clear them.  Back in the day, when some of us smoked pipes with screens in them, it was easy to burn them clean, -when that didn't work anymore, replacement pipe screens were about ten cents apiece.  Liked the sound quality but expected more than 5 months out of these ear-canal phones.-After writing this review and contemplating for a bit, I simply used a sewing needle to remove the tiny screen from each ear-piece. Now they seem to be good as new!  For the price, these things are a good value.  I use them for working out, bicycling (off the street), and inline skating.  I've accidentally yanked them out of my ears a few times with no ill effects.

Did not try with gaming, but as a workstation monitor extender, awesome unit. Highly recommend. I drove two separate monitors 19x12 without problem. I was very impressed with the units performance. reviewText: Product is well packaged and does what it says. I knocked a star off for two reasons....1. The driver installation program has issues. It took nearly 5 minutes to install on a dual XEON Intel MB vs what typically requires seconds... it reported it failed to install when it actually did install. I tried it 3-4 times with same results... shoddy execution on the software but it eventually got the job done.2. The board is mechanically off a little on its bracket height relative to the PCI design spec and bottoms in the MB connector before the I/O bracket can bottom on the chassis rear panel flange. This is not an uncommon execution error with respect to PCI / PCI-e card design (I'm an R&D; engineer in the business and have seen this on many boards since the dawn of the PC). This won't prevent it from working, but if your chassis has some bad fit tolerance (mine does) and it's in the wrong direction, when you tighten the screw down on the I/O bracket, it could "jack" the board up to where it does not make proper contact. Just something to watch out for. Mine works fine in one slot, but not another I tried.
summary: As described but has some annoying installation issues.

reviewText: I have owned a number of Canon G cameras including the G3 and G9. I think this is a very worthy successor to the line. After a month of ownership, about 750 pictures and thousands of miles travelled with it, I can report that I am very pleased with it. My primary needs for this camera are something compact that I can throw in a carry on bag for travel or something that I can conveniently grab at home for a party or for Internet images. It must have excellent image quality, offer advanced features and controls and accept an external flash. The G11 meets all of these requirements and offers a few bonus features such as a built in ND filter, very good video (but non-HD which I don't care about) and a superb swivel display.I find camera operation very straightforward and I really appreciate the abundance of dials for ISO, Exposure Compensation, Modes and more. For me, it feels faster than software menus and is easily double checked visually. Power up is fast as is autofocus and I have rarely found myself waiting for the camera to catch up to me. This makes it well suited for travel or child photography where you must seize the moment. The lens range is excellent, particularly the wide end of 28 mm which again is very useful for travel where you may be shooting in tight interiors or trying to capture groups of people or large vistas. As with all lenses of this type, there is noticeable barrel distortion at the wide end which is correctable in post processing. Shooting small product images for auctions or sharing on the Internet is easy with the macro mode and the swiveling screen. The flash does a fair job of throttling down for close range. Macro shots might work better with a bounced external flash such as the 270EX though. Speaking of the 270EX, it makes a perfect mate for this camera because it is so small but still offers bounce capability. I am able to squeeze it into the Tamrac travel case that I use for the camera.The creative possibilities with the G11 are tremendous since output is really very good and the artistic control and features are so comprehensive. Kudos to Canon for the brave move of downsizing the megapixel count and focusing on image quality. The improvement in ISOs above 80 is very significant - I used it repeatedly at ISO 400 on a recent trip. With my old G9 I would not have considered using this setting because of the cost in image noise and quality. Battery life in my experience is very good and reliability overall for the camera looks promising since I used it in rain, sub-zero and hot temperatures without a hitch.If there are any drawbacks to the camera for me, they are that the controls are a little crowded for my average male hands and the multipurpose rotary dial on the back could use improvement, it is too cramped and spins too easily. The camera is otherwise so good that I don't mind working around this.
summary: Sweet Travel or General Purpose Camera!

reviewText: This amp continues a long line of superior products from Fosgate I've used over the years.  Mine came right out of the box factory rated at 332 watts RMS.  I currently have it running to 6.5 components and a set of tweeters....soon to add the rear channels with 6x9's.  I have the gain turned to almost the lowest possible setting and it sounds excellent.  For the price, I don't think you could get a better amp.  The size is very good as well, about the size of a medium hard back book.  Fits nicely under the front seat.

reviewText: I don't normally get uppity in my reviews, but D-Link has really burned a bridge with me on this one.  They have named this product in a deceptive and misleading way.  It's too bad "AC1200" is a marketing term with no legal binding, and it's too bad D-Link is exploiting this fact to sell this hobbled product.From the Product Description:"The D-Link Dual Band AC1200 Adapter (DWA-182) *** provides up to 300/867 Mbps performance *** and dual band technology to ensure top Wi-Fi speeds and reliable connections. The DWA-182 adapter is backward compatible with existing Wi-Fi devices and is ideal for upgrading your notebook or desktop with the latest generation of wireless performance." -- (*** emphasis mine)So the key part of this rant relates to this claim:  "provides up to 300/867 Mbps performance"If you break the 802.11 standards of these products down, you get the marketing terms you see on these newer AC networking products:AC750:  300mbps 802.11n + 433mbps 802.11ac ~= 750mbps thus "750"AC1200:  300mbps 802.11n + 867mbps 802.11ac ~= 1200mbpsetcThe problem with this product is that it uses the USB 2.0 interface, which *is limited to 480mbps* - almost half the 867mbps available through the 5GHz radio in this adapter.So if D-Link had simply labeled it an AC750 device (it effectively is), and had not given the completely false Product Description above (read it again), I'd have rated this higher and not complained at all - because I'd have been an informed customer and known what I was getting up front.  The adapter does peg out the USB port it is plugged into, and performs well - at ~480mbps.They cannot make the above claim in the Description, even if the radio within is capable of it, the system as manufactured is not.  Back it goes.  I hope this saves someone the hassle or getting cheated out of money.There are several other 802.11ac adapters out now that do have USB 3.0 interfaces (which would let you get closer to the full benefit of 802.11ac):- Edimax EW-7822UAC- ASUS USB-AC56- ZyXEL 11ac- Linksys WUSB6300- Rosewill AC1200UBEthough some of these have mediocre/crappy ratings.  I will update this review with a blurb about the Edimax when I receive it.Maybe D-Link will try to justify this in a reply (they seem to be watching these reviews).  To address anticipated response:"But you can't really get 867mbps even with USB 3.0"- no, but I can get closer to it than 480mbps.  That your product easily pegs out a USB 2.0 port (with nothing in its controller mate - they are usually ported in pairs on motherboards) shows that I can expect a USB 3.0 adapter to go well above this.  Change the marketing term used for this model to AC750, the Product Description to what's honest, and I'll have no complaint.
summary: Not AC1200 performance, D-Link misleading on this one

reviewText: I bought these for a couple of reasons 1) I had a previous pair in Black and Red and loved the sound that came from them 2) They are one of the few earbuds that are Sheathed for less than $100 3) the color of these actually matched my bike perfectly (dorky, I know)I wear these earbuds while cycling. The sound is fantastic for the price, however, I also noticed that the position of the earbud in my ear determines the dampening of the bass.Here's my problem and why they get a 3 star review: I bought these because of the full metal quality and for me the braided sheathed earbud wires were the key selling point for me. After awhile, small part of the plastic wire came through the braiding (like a Hernia) and sure enough, only a week later, so much of the wire came through that it separated the entire braided sheath and is now completely exposed.I still use the earbuds because I'm the type who will use something until it's dead, but I am terribly disappointed with the Braided Sheath wearing and eventually exposing the wire.PROS:+ Love the Braided Sheath wires+ Appreciate the Full Metal construction+ Great color combination (I think this was intentional to match popular bike colors, great idea Skullcandy)CONS:- Braided sheath wears easily and quickly exposes the wire (please improve, I will buy these again)- Earbud suction causes bass to be minimized

It's small, discreet, black to match my other components and at a great price, I highly recommend this product.

Check.I have tried several different screen protectors to protect my iBaby, and this one ranks right up there in terms of quality. We bought this Vizio E291i-A1 Smart TV from Amazon for use in front of our treadmill. It was easy to setup and works as expected. We use this smart TV to connect thru our dual band router to Netflix and other streaming sources. We also have it connected to DirecTV. As I recall, to attached the TV base/stand to the TV you need a Phillips screwdriver with a #1 blade/tip and a shank of over one inch (to fit thru the opening in the base). I started the two screws in the TV to condition the threads, unscrewed them, snapped the base into the TV, stood the TV on edge on a bed (mattress), and put in the screws. With this approach it was easy. We used free shipping from Amazon, but the TV arrived at least a week before the original estimate. The TV comes with a Quick Start Guide which is adequate. We downloaded the manual from Vizio. We had tried first to buy this Vizio model from a big box store, and they sold us a TV in a box that looked unopened. Turns out the big box store TV we bought was not a smart TV and the model and serial # of the TV in the box did not match the model or serial number on the label or receipt. We got a full refund from the big box store and ordered the TV from Amazon.
summary: Vizio E291i-A1 Smart TV from Amazon
