reviewText: I've owned this lens for a few months now - bought as an alternative to my 18-200 kit lens on my 60D.  The image quality of this lens is quite amazing.  The kit lens is decent but the 60mm has a real punch to it.  It likes light... lots of it - and is a breeze to use.  In low light conditions I really have to watch the shutter speed. If hand held in AV mode the trick is to find the right balance between aperture and bumping up the ISO to achieve an acceptable shutter speed. One can always use a tripod but I get a bit lazy in that aspect. There is no IS with this lens so if I can keep the shutter speed at 1/100th of a second or faster handheld then I'm usually confident in avoiding any movement blurring.  Just depends on how steady you are. I've done some handhelds around 1/30 - 1/60 sec and lucked out too but the keeper rate is low for me.I use this lens the majority of times... street fairs, outdoor events, touristy/travel places, hiking and as a portrait lens.  It does challenge one to really think about composition as its equivalent to a 96mm lens on a crop sensor and my legs are the zoom factor.  I certainly can't overlook its macro abilities either.  The macro realm to me is quite demanding and many factors come into play but this lens can produce some amazing results.  I'm often floored, macro or not, viewing my pictures at 100%.  If you've nailed the focus you will see details that can be astounding!  Fire up your cropping tools in favorite photo editor and you'll find yourself getting several keepers out of 1 shot depending on what you want to emphasize.I find the USM focusing quite fast w/ very little hunting.  It seems really well built and its smaller form factor is a bonus when carrying around.  Less conspicuous and you don't feel like you've got a trumpet mounted on your camera body such as when my 18-200 is on full zoom.Bottom line - you will love this lens.  Dare I say it's almost "L" series in the quality of photos it takes?  This lens makes you work and pushes one to become a better photographer.  I don't feel the need to own a nifty or thrifty 50mm w/ this lens.  Perhaps the lower light capability with the 50's would be nice but with my shooting styles I find a way to work around it and deal with it.  Personally, I think everyone needs a good prime lens and for me - this is the one!

I purchased these earbuds in October 2010 and have not had any regrets with my purchase.The sound quality is great for listening to music and podcasts for on my walk to work, and phone calls come through nice and clear as well.I've not had any complaints about the quality of my voice through the attached microphone, and I can speak at a normal volume level to be clearly heard (even while walking outside in light winds).The inline volume controls and multi-function button (play, pause, answer, hang-up, voice control) work great as well and have been very handy to have.I love these earbuds, so you may be wondering why I only give them 4 stars out of 5.  There are 2 main reasons:1.) Build Quality.  So far these have lasted very nicely, but I feel certain that in the next few months they'll likely die off, just like my old Sony earbuds did after 6-8 months that were built the exact same way (minus the microphone and volume controls).  I have a newer set of Sony earbuds, the Sony MDR-XB40EX (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001RB24U0/ref=oss_product), that has a much nicer build quality and a tangle-free cord that isn't so skinny that I feel like it's going to break at any second.2.) This set of earbuds came with a small velvety bag to carry them in that attracts all kinds of dust and lint.  I don't actually use this bag, instead I use the very nice carrying case that came with my Sony MDR-XB40EX earbuds instead as it has a semi hard card that feels like it provides significantly more protection.Overall I am very happy with this set of earbuds for my iPhone and I would recommend them to anyone, especially at the price listed on Amazon :)  Compared to similarly priced earbuds with inline controls and microphone these are a steal!

Contrary to other reviews, this case will fit the Sony RX100 and the magnetic flap will close firmly like it should.  The trick is you have to put the camera in back side out.  If you put the camera in lens side out, the flap on the case will not fold over completely and will not hold shut.  I also removed the inner memory card pocket just so it wouldn't fit quite as snug - just flip the case inside out and gently cut the stitching on the memory card pocket.  Using this technique, the case fits the camera very snugly but the flap makes complete magnetic contact with the case and stays shut very well.This is a slim case which is good for carrying in your pocket.  It's completely soft so offers little protection from drops but keeps the scratches off while it's in your pocket or purse.  I've used it for years with my Canon S90 and it's held up very well.  I'm now looking forward to using it for several more years with my RX100.
summary: Indeed fits Sony RX100 with a small trick

But that night, I had a dream, and in my dream I saw me replacing two of the long holders with two of the short holders, then miraculously pulling the sides apart and placing the iPad inside to be held securely. When I looked at the holder the next morning, I could not see how it came apart. But I tried anyway. It came apart. Then I looked at the instructions. That's exactly how it is supposed to work. And the strong spring makes it difficult to pull the sides apart and continue to hold them apart while inserting the iPad. Careful! reviewText: I have owned several thinkpads over the years, including several after Lenovo took over the computer line.  This is the first Lenovo I have bought that is a real disappointment.  I'm not a gamer; I just wanted the performance, large disk space, and graphics for photo work.While the screen and graphics display is very nice, there are major hardware (and possibly software driver) issues that I have not been able to resolve.  The touch pad is too sensitive, so unless you cover it while typing, you end up having keyboard issues, where the mouse randomly jumps to different places on the screen while typing.The other major issue (which I've yet to resolve) is the wireless connection - it randomly disconnects, even though it shows it's connected.  And you have to dis-connect and re-connect to get to work again.In summary:1) mouse pad/ keyboard issues - bad hardware design?2) wireless randomly drops - not sure if it's bad hardware design or software drivers (I uploaded the latest drivers)Very sad that you end up paying $1200 for something that has such major issues.  Did no one test these products in the prototype stage?  Did no one test them before shipping?  It's unfortunate that all the PC manufacturers seem to have gone down in quality.  I would rather pay a little more and get a better product, and I always thought Lenovo to have higher quality than other manufacturers.  I'm not sure my next one will be a Lenovo.  I hope they realize to keep the customers they had, they must improve their quality!
summary: Just OK, disappointed in Lenovo, quality and possibly design issues

We live in an OS-agnostic household, so there are PCs as well as Macs that require backups on a regular basis. And, sure, perhaps hard drive storage looks relatively primitive nowadays with the prevalence of "cloud" storage, but, hey, sometimes Internet access isn't always available, and I still trust physical hardware to store important stuff in a pinch. The Seagate Backup 3.0 is ready-made for Macs, installs and is ready-to-use immediately. A great buy, as well, for the Terrabyte capacity for under $100. I don't remember how I came to learn about this tool, but I bought it in a store for my Nikon D300 without reading any reviews.  I did try it out in the store and I was immediately impressed with the results so I bought it on the spot.The disk is amazingly well packaged.  It's packaged just like an iPod that I received some years back.  It doesn't have the scrimpy, we-don't-care Made-In-China feel.  It comes with a lanyard, a semi-rigid pouch that you can attach to your belt, a CD with all of the PDF instructions in multiple languages and a how-to video.Their web-site also has instructions on how to set the Nikon D300 pre settings.For years, from the time I got my first DSLR I've been plagued by color balance issues.  It seems that I have to color correct each and every photograph in Photoshop.  I shoot in RAW so that I have more control but it takes so much more work and time.  I'm also not very good with color correctly with PS.  I have all the instructions and I follow them carefully, but I always had problems getting the hang of it.I own gray cards but they're bulky and I don't walk around with one.  I also haven't had very good luck with them either. I'm sure it's my technique but I never did get the hang of it.Shooting under artificial light is a real pain. Auto WB never really works.I first tried the ExpoDisk in a room lit with CFs (Compact Fluorescent) bulbs.  I used the ExpoDisk as directed and I received absolutely perfect results the first time.  Then I tried another room lit with LEDs.  Again, perfect results.  I put a Gretamacbeth colorchecker chart in each of my test shots.  Every time, the whites are whites and the blacks are black. Zero color cast.I've never been able to photograph granite and achieve the correct color. After using the ExpoDisk, the granite color perfectly matches the first time.  When photographing faces, I'm utterly clueless obtaining the correct tones unless I have a Gretamacbeth colorchecker chart in the photograph and fiddle around with Photoshop.  Again, ExpoDisk to the rescue.Maybe it's the camera or maybe it's me, but I also have problems with color casts using a flash with the color balance set to flash.  The ExpoDisk washed those problems away.Shooting under different lighting sources is a challenge.  Which do I aim at?  Unfortunately, the ExpoDisk never addresses that issue.  I probably have to use colored gels on the flash (I have the SB-900 and SB-800's) to neutralize the fluorescent bulbs.I don't intend to use this while casually walking around but when I want to be certain that the color balance is perfect, then I use the ExpoDisk.  Even at 77mm (the size of my largest lens so that it will fit all my other lenses) it's small enough to carry around in my pocket.  I don't know if I'm dorky enough to put it on my belt.The hardest time I had with this was getting the lanyard cord through the hole. The only way I could get that thick cord through the tiny hole was to take a sewing thread to make a loop and pull the lanyard cord through the hole.I've spent thousands of dollars on camera equipment but I've had so many problems getting the color balance correct and this relatively small investment has already saved me a lot of grief.  So perhaps I'm incompetent with Photoshop and gray cards, but this resolves so many of my problems to begin with.I can now shoot in RAW/JPG and directly use the JPGs when I don't need to adjust the exposure. Another time saver.I strongly recommend the ExpoDisk if you're serious about photography and want perfect color balance the first time.
summary: An amazing tool for obtaining correct color balance.

reviewText: After a lot of research, I purchased the 905 last year. Onkyo had some production issues (strong demand) and so I waited MONTHS before one became available. On paper, the specs look very good.Ultimately, Onkyo bought-back my receiver from me because of several design flaws that firmware updates could not fix. For example, the DSPs are poorly designed such that there is a delay of 2-3 seconds when locking onto and audio stream. So every time I fast-forward through a commercial, the video plays for 2-3 seconds with no audio. Changing audio streams on Blu-Ray movies had the same delay.In addition, there is a significant audio delay that causes a mis-sync between audio and video. Again, Onkyo says a firmware update cannot fix the problem. I bypassed the Reon video processor to help with the problem, but then you lose the built-in scaling feature.Only service centers are permitted to do firmware updates. In my case, there was a 2-3 week backlog. Thankfully, one update leaked to the internet and I was able to do it myself. However, Onkyo found out about the leak and was not happy.Onkyo also makes no mention of any firmware updates on their web site. So unless a consumer calls in regarding a problem, they will never know an update is out there. They should clearly state on their product support web site an update is available and to call their service center for more information.If they can fix these and other defects in the 906 model (due mid 2008), then it would be a winner. But the 905 has so many issues that I switched receivers and now own a Denon. For more insight to the problems, check out the avsforum site where there is a large discussion on this model.
summary: Good specs, poor implementation - don't buy

I live in a rental house, so I can't run cat 5 wiring through the walls.  I subscribe to Frontier FIOS, and needed a more reliable way to get remote devices on my network than wireless or AC line adapters.  These fit the bill PERFECTLY!  Installation was effortless, and the first unit I plugged in connected to my Verizon router over MOCA in approximately 10 seconds.  The download and upload speeds are exactly the same as when the PC is plugged directly into the router via cat 5 cables.  The second unit I plugged in joined the network just as easily.  Super fast, and super reliable.  There has been NO lost connection between these units and my router.  It is much more fun watching things on Netflix on my networked blu-ray player than when I had the AC plug adapters.  Much faster buffering, better picture quality due to higher speeds, etc.  These are one of the best networking solutions I've ever used.

I have several of these, in different colors, and they work perfectly on my Fire and Touch. I really enjoy using them instead of my finger, because they keep fingerprints off the screen, and are usually more accurate than my fingers. Definitely recommend them. Great color choices, too.

The pluses of this camera are that the video view over the web is acceptable for surveillance.  And, once you get it working, it works.The minuses of this camera are that the installation process can be fidgity.  On my home computer, where I first installed it, I had trouble getting the network to recognize the camera.  I have a network hub leading from my main router, and it absolutely had to be plugged into the main router to work.  Once I got the hard wired network connection working, it took several attempts to get the wireless recognized.  I tried using the push button set up for the wireless.  Maybe it matters that I have a Linksys router, but the automated setup wouldn't work.  After I set the camera up at home and tested it I took it to my business.At my business I had more problems with the setup.  For some reason, with the network cable attached the camera kept grabbing the same IP address as the point of sale system.  I had to give the point of sale system a fixed IP and exclude it from the DHCP range.  Then I had to set up the camera and go into the desktop local web interface that is accessed from the camera's ip address.  Once I got there I gave the camera a fixed IP for the LAN.  I still had some trouble getting the wireless to work.  I tried using the push button set up.  Again, maybe because my router is a Linksys, it didn't work.  I was able to manually set up the wireless by using the web interface and typing in the password.Once I got it set up it seems to be working pretty well as a way to see into my business when I'm not there.  However, the sound barely works - it cuts in and out - mostly out.  This camera is really intended for uses like monitoring dogs during the day.  Since I know that all my dogs do is sleep I thought I'd try it at my business.  It would be nicer if the sound works.  DLink needs to fix the installation.
So far so good for this product protecting my son's new IPOD. You can't connect to a normal docking station but the regular USB cable fits just fine.

I'm rather heavy into the flight sim hobby for some years now and I wanted a larger monitor even tho' I have two 24" monitors but I first looked at a 32" monitor but the reviews when you step up to that size screen for use on a PC computer [versus as a TV or satellite monitor] is that the DPI on reading computer text especially on the internet can suffer when one uses the monitor 'other' than flight simming and switches to the internet so I settled on the 27" and this monitor filled the bill perfectly and is not a wallet buster not to mention Prime free shipping.That all said, a few things to keep in mind. First and foremost, DO NOT let anyone tell you that when you get into larger monitors [24" and over] that any dead pixels should be "expected" and on large monitors used for either TV, satellite TV or a PC [or 'whatever'] that "one or more dead pixels are the nature of the beast" -- this is complete nonsense! You should expect NO dead pixels whatsoever and if you see one, pack the monitor back up, go to Amazon returns and do the returns thing with the free UPS shipping label as a "defective" item and send it back for a replacement or a refund! You did not pay for 'any' dead pixels and this is one of the very first things you should check thoroughly when the monitor comes to life! What you should expect is a monitor free of any dead pixels or any other problems! Case closed! Hey, it's your money and your call but problems right out the box with 'any' new item should not be tolerated and doesn't have to be tolerated when a no hassle returns policy is in place and as is the case with Amazon who will make good on any defective items! And they have their 3rd party Amazon vendors follow suit!Now, notice that the monitor only ships with a DVI cable and a 15 pin VGA cable. Please note that a DVI cable and an HDMI cable [not provided] produce the exact same HDMI signal with the only difference being that an HDMI cable carries its own audio. There is NO difference in picture quality! You are also provided with a green coded PC audio cable but the speakers are not a strong point  of 'most' monitors that have them and you're looking at two 3 watt speakers to boot with a sound quality that is tinny at best! OK, OK, make that read "stereo" tinniness then and your best bet is to stick with your after-market speakers for decent sound  reproduction.Finally this, an HD monitor can spoil you! When you get it, go over to YouTube and check out some of the HD [but 1080p quality] clips. Very often I'll watch HD clips on 'real' airplanes, both take offs and landings and especially night landings and with 1080p HD, you'll swear you're right in the jump seat behind the pilot and first officer and the view can be quite spectacular. A little mechanical gear icon will come up in YouTube at the very bottom right of the screen to alert you that the clip is in HD although in some cases and even if your setting is in "auto", you can try to increase the HD level from 360p all the way up to the top to 1080p, if, of course, the original featured clip was filmed in that specification, 1080p.This too, this monitor will [or at least should] automatically fit your Windows screen. Some of the older HDMI screens came up too wide cutting out Windows icons but this can be easily remedied within the MONITOR buttons. Do NOT lower the resolution [in this monitor, 1920 X 1080] or you lose the benefit of the best picture! In older HDMI monitors, just make sure that the monitor setting is set to "PC" and NOT 'AV'! As I said tho', this Asus model will automatically fit your screen. Note to flight simmers! FSX will automatically detect the presence of an HDMI 1920 X 1080 monitor but for FS9 [2004] be sure to set the resolution for your new HDMI monitor using your OLD perhaps higher res monitor [the old favorite box shaped 1920 X 1200] and set FS9 to a lower HDMI resolution or the FS9 will give you what looks like a multi-strobe filled nightclub effect until you "fix" the new HDMI resolution especially if you are using dual [or more!] monitors which is very popular in flight simming. BTW, and again for flight sim enthusiasts, check out the successor to Helge Schroeder's fantastic FlightNav 4.7 which was great for FS98 through FS9 [2004] but will ==NOT== work in FSX but Helge's relatively new FSTramp [sic] nav program does work in FSX and works very well! As for those new Saitek external modules, and sold on Amazon, check out my reviews on them but don't forget to have two 'required' programs if you're thinking of buying any of those modules for your home sim set-up -- the Saitek module 25.7MB driver [or SPAD alternative driver] ==and== Pete Dowson's equally fantastic FSUIPC program. BOTH are required for the Saitek modules to work correctly. Enjoy!Doc Tony
summary: Excellent ... but some things to note and keep in mind

This Laptop/Notebook Cooling Pad is great.  This item does the job.  Yes, as many others say, the plastic construction is somewhat cheap and thin but for $6 you cant beat it.  The 3 fans really cool down my laptop dramatically.  My laptop would get so hot it would turn off and with this cooling pad that no longer happens.  The blue LED's are a cool accent in my opinion and help with lighting in a dark room.  I have a 15" laptop which takes up more than the size of the actual cooling fan but it holds well with the supplied rubber/plastic grip pads on the top and bottom of the cooling pad.  The only downfall other than the cheap plastic construction would be that you cant have it on your lap because of the fan location.  Also, if you have a flexible laptop lap setting, the fans will still hit.  The cooling pad MUST be on a hard flat surface that does not flex.  I can't speak for the duration/lifetime of this item as I have only had it for about a week but if you are looking for something a bit more rugged or tough, I would recommend going with a name brand product.  If you are looking for a quick fix and are on a tight budget, I highly recommend getting this item.

As a headphone novice, I debated what I wanted and the most important features. As a commuter, I wanted something portable that would offer some isolation.I tested the Bose QC20i and the M-100s on a flight from the US to India so I had adequate time with each. The Bose noise canceling is as good as advertised but I didn't like the battery pack or the pressure sensation in my ears. Both were worse than expected.I decided that the volume and punch of the M-100 suited me more despite some concerns. It wasn't until I tried the Momentums during a layover in Frankfurt that I began to question my decision.Even though the M-100 seemed powerful and well built, I was frustrated by the negative effect that the bass had on the vocals, particularly for Rock tracks (i.e., Pearl Jam, Foo Fighters). Worse still, the metal arms scratched the very first time I zipped them into the case. The case is so compact that the elastic straps meant to hold the cables actually position the metal ends in contact with the arms. I rated the M-100 at 4 stars just the same because V Moda was willing to replace them as a result if the scratching issue.I decided to test the Momentums and was struck by a few things. The leather ear pads feel better than the pleather on the M-100s and the ear pieces rotate allowing for a more precise, comfortable fit. They were also much lighter to wear. Those factors, combined with crisp, detailed audio pushed me over the top and I simply returned the M-100s.I'm not "headphone guy" who will have $1000 - $2000 invested in multiple headphones and decided that in this price range, the Momentum offered the best comfort and quality. I am a bit concerned by the flimsy feel of the cable over the long-term but preferred every other aspect.The only reason that this set didn't earn 5 stars is the cost of replacement cables for long-term use. The cable is currently available through Sennheiser for $92 US.

On the whole, I am pleasantly surprised that this inexpensive little switch works as well as it does.  I was also pleasantly surprised to see that the switch will recognize Num Lock key-presses as well as Scroll Lock.  (Scroll Lock can be problematic due to the horrible F Lock key arrangement on Microsoft keyboards.)I am using it with a Microsoft wireless keyboard and mouse set, which has one USB connector and one PS2 connector (disconnected).  It seems fully compatible with the mouse and keyboard.  All the special keys and mouse buttons work just as when directly connected.I am only using the keyboard and mouse portion of the switch since both computers have their own monitors, so I can't speak to display quality or performance.The only major problem I've found is the one others have reported with VMware.  When moving the mouse in and out of a VMware window where a VM is running, it can cause the switch to jump to the other computer.  Worse, if VMware is set for the VM to capture new USB devices when in focus (I believe this is the default), it will try to connect to the KVM directly when you switch it back to the first computer.  So, there is no way to regain keyboard and mouse control on the first computer without removing the switch and directly connecting the keyboard/mouse.  I don't think this is a problem so much with this switch as with VMware itself, which apparently generates multiple Scroll Lock and/or Num Lock key-presses when switching focus to/from the VMs; so I'm guessing any KVM switch that uses these keystrokes would be affected.You should also know that switching between computers effectively disconnects the USB keyboard and mouse device(s) from the first computer and connects them to the second one.  This generates a cacophony of Windows kerplonk USB connect and disconnect sounds along with causing a couple of seconds of delay before the keyboard and mouse are connected to the new computer.  Not a big problem, but something to keep in mind.  Given the way this works, a simple mechanical USB A/B switch might work just as well or better for my needs.My only other minor gripe is that I have to press Num Lock (or Scroll Lock) twice more slowly than is natural (about 1/2 second between presses).  Any quicker and the switch does not seem recognize the keystrokes and doesn't switch between PCs.The little instruction booklet that comes with the switch is put together in an interesting way.  It seems to flow from back to front with no real rhyme or reason as to how the different languages are ordered.  Whole pages of Russian, French, etc. are interspersed seemingly at random with English pages.  I don't mind having the other languages in there, but the random layout must be a printing mistake which doesn't speak well to quality control.None of these issues would prevent my from keeping this switch, except for VMware which I use frequently.  I've not yet found an acceptable workaround for this, so I'm going to try the simpler IOGear switch that has a wired remote button and may not be sensitive to these keystrokes.  The reviews of that switch have me questioning whether it will work with the wireless mouse and keyboard, but I'm going to give it a try.Update:  I received the IOGear GCS22U switch with the wired remoteIOGear 2-Port USB KVM Switch with Cables and Remote GCS22U (Black).  It works just as well as this Trendnet for my needs, but avoids the issue with VMware altogether since it does not listen for Num Lock or Scroll Lock.  I actually prefer the IOGear's small wired remote in any case.

It seemed to happen most when more than one PC was connected via wireless.  At other times, it would work flawlessly for 30 minutes or more.  The same USB modem works flawlessly when connected directly to either laptop that I use. I purchased this receiver in June 2010 and so have had time to digest all the options and features of this product so that I can provide a fair review.  I use this receiver primarily for home theater and its been excellent so I rate the product 5 stars.  I havent run into the video issues that have been mentioned in prior posts.  Currently, my receiver powers two Polk RTi10 floor standing speakers, a HSU subwoofer, a Polk CSi A6 center channnel speaker and two Polk bookshelf rear speakers.  Its connected to my Panasonic 50" LCD projection TV via HDMI and the main input is a Sony BDP 570 blu ray player connected via HDMI.  It took me about 6 months to really tweak the setting to my liking but thats one of the great features about this reciever is that there are numerous options to change the sound to your preference.  The first and most obvious thing to do once your ready is to run the Audyssey 2EQ Speaker Setup function and then you can tweak from there, if needed.A few things to note that I gathered from trial and error and from trolling all the AVS forums about this receiver.  When I first started playing blu ray movies I noticed the dialogue tended to be very weak and the explosions and sound effects were very loud.  All the speakers were connected properly and it wasnt the blu ray player because I tried a different brand player and got the same results.  To solve this problem, I found that setting the Onkyo Dynamic Volume option from OFF to LIGHT makes a huge difference in sound.  It will do a light compression on the sound, which some audio purist may be opposed to but it makes the dialogue so much better and louder and based on what I hear, it doesnt degrade the overall sound at all.  Just make sure you have a decent center channel speaker to handle it, otherwise you might have to decrease the center speaker setting down a couple of db's.  The other thing I noticed is that this reciever has a Late Night setting which lowers the overall volume for evening viewing if you don't want to wake your neighbors.  This setting is defaulted to Auto.  However, when playing certain movies it will trigger the Late Night feature and the volume is very muted.  This happened to me when I played Star Trek and I realized that I need to switch the Late Night setting from Auto to OFF.  This makes a big difference in sound.  The feature only applies for discs with Dolby True HD sound.  The final observation I made was that the volume level will typically be at a 50% setting for decent sound.  I initially thought this was too high because my old Technics reciever would get really loud when I had the volume turned up to 25%.  I found out later that 50% is about right and its not an issue of weakness in the reciever because this reciever is plenty powerful.As a final note, I purchased this product on Amazon and received it no problem with free shipping and no taxes so rest assured that Amazon's delivery is just as reliable for electronics as it is for books.  When I ordered this it was based on reading countless reviews here and on CNET and other audio video websites and forums.  I never went to any store to physically test out the product so it was a leap of faith on my part that I was ordering based soley on what I read and Onkyo's reputation for putting out quality audio equipment.  So far I have not been disappointed in my decision.UPDATE July 2013: I decided to recently retire this receiver and upgrade to a Marantz receiver.  In hindsight, looking back on my experience with this product I would say that it wasn't great.  I'm saying this because after hearing the sound produced from the Marantz when compared to the Onkyo I find that the Marantz produces a more balanced and warmer sound whereas the Onkyo sounds a little more harsh when the volume is turned up.  Also, for some reason whenever I start up a movie with the Onkyo it seems like the sound is a tad muted so I would go into the receiver menu options and switch the dynamic volume from Light to Off and back to Light and that would bring the sound back to normal levels.  I had to do this everytime I watched a movie and it would only work for movies encoded in DTS-MA.  Additionally, I had some HDMI issues where I would suddenly lose video and audio in the middle of a 3D movie.  I had to tinker with the connections for a few hours by trying other receiver inputs which seemed to work but I would run into instances where the video would show but the audio would cut in and out.  Eventually everything started working again and I couldn't tell if it was because of my tinkering or it just fixed itself.  So that experience left me a little uneasy.  One note - if you are watching high definition in Blu Ray with this receiver then one of the biggest adjustments you need to do is to turn off the video processing function.  The details on how to do that can be found in the other reviews here.  I can tell you it makes a huge difference in video quality especially if you are sending a 1080p 24fps video signal from the player and the tv is 1080p compatible.  The video processer really dulls down the picture but if you turn it off the picture is a lot sharper and pops from the screen.  At the end of the day I felt that the combination of all the tweaking and adjustments that you need to make to get around all the different issues encountered with this receiver did not warrant a 5 star rating product and therefore I downgraded the rating accordingly even though this is a discontinued product.
summary: Some home theater tips for this receiver

Windows 8.I've been working with it since it was available for consumers to test.  I found it confusing and unintuitive.  Frustrated, after just a few days, I uninstalled the test version and reinstalled Windows 7 on my personal, home-built desktop machine.When Windows 8 was released, I decided I would try it again.  I bought Windows 8 from Amazon and installed it.  It was still awful.  The interface was still confusing... and I have been using PCs since the IBM PC was introduced in the early eighties.  I couldn't believe what a blunder Microsoft made.  What were they thinking, putting this tablet/phone-like operating system on a desktop?  Nobody is going to reach up and swipe icons across their desktop monitor.Recently I received this Logitech T650 Touchpad from Amazon.  I already own their K800 Wireless Keyboard.  It's excellent.Upon installing the T650 and working with it, I have found that it makes a NIGHT AND DAY DIFFERENCE in my interaction with Windows 8.  Really.So I have come to the conclusion that Windows 8 was designed to be used on a desktop computer with a touchpad.  Using a mouse instead of a touchpad works, but really doesn't do justice to the Windows 8 interface.  (I think Microsoft needs to get the word out.)The Logitech T650 Touchpad is well built.  Like my K800 keyboard, it's wireless and rechargeable.  After working with it for just a few hours, I was easily comfortable with it.I plan to keep Windows 8 installed on my desktop machine.  The Logitech T650 makes a lot of difference.  I recommend this product and would buy it again.Tom
summary: Don't use Windows 8 without this Touchpad!

reviewText: I bought this transmitter with very low expectations and have been nothing but impressed with the quality of sound produced so far. In my old Toyota pickup and new Corolla, it sounds better than even the clearest radio stations. I recommend that you use a lower frequency, as close to 88.1 as possible, because I found a significant difference in sound quality between the lower range and upper range, expecially in the lower bass and upper treble registers. (I don't know if there is any scientific reason for this, it was just my experience) I live in the boondocks, so I don't have much frequency competition to worry about, though.

The iPod Hi-Fi can fill my photo studio with music better than any other portable stereo I've owned. Listening to music outside on my patio without having to run inside to change volume etc is a joy, and the sound is as good as my Bose exterior speakers. The ability to mount multiple generations of iPods is a huge plus. When my color iPod was stolen, I dusted off my old 3G iPod, and it works seamlessly with the Hi-Fi. The remote changes songs and does everything I need. If you have an current generation video iPod, it can even change the EQ to what you prefer when listening to the speakers as opposed to with ear speakers. (I've tested this feature with my wife's iPod, and it is really cool.)  I just wish that Apple had made a way to attach the remote to the unit for transport. I'm sure I'll end up buying one or two remotes at some point.

reviewText: If you want hassle free, no stress synchronization between your apple computer, iPhone, iPod touch and iPad then get mobile me.Though it is pricy, if you buy directly from Apple, it is definitely worth the 65 bucks i paid for here on amazon.  Me and my wife were always trying to get each others calendar dates synced so we would email each other our schedules and put them in manually on our devices and computer so we can all be on the same page but at changed when i got mobile me.Now she can put her schedule in on our phone and ill get it on mine along with my iPad, or computer and on the mobile me site. Any time I have to put a new contact or edit a contact she gets the same information across the board. And that's just a fraction of what mobile me is.I love Gallery, when i need to free up space on my phone, i send my photos and videos to the MobileMe gallery which happens to be paired up with my IPhoto so whatever i upload is in my iPhoto without me having to connect my phone to import my photos. iDisk is just as amazing, though i wish there was more flexibility within the iPhone app i still think it's an over all amazing product.I recommend this to anyone who wants to sync multiple devices without having to manually do it on each one. It's stress free and it's definitely worth the price.

reviewText: We bought this as a gift for my wife's sister and her family, and I had the pleasure of setting it up. It was actually really simple, but we did have to run to CVS for an HDMI cable (they only include a standard RCA video cable). One oddity: it could be their older TV, but I couldn't get the audio to transfer over HDMI. The Roku allows plugging in both the RCA and the HDMI cables at the same time though, and that worked fine.Since I also bought anApple TVfor my mom, I could compare the two devices from unboxing and setup, to use. Roku wins hands-down on most points, much to my surprise. I'm addicted to Apple products, and figured that spending a little extra on my mom was the smart move. In the end, I wish I'd have gotten her the Roku. Roku feels more like an Apple product than the Apple TV - it has apps, an app store (with fun games even!), and an easy-to-use interface. Apple's interface by contrast is pretty, but more complicated in structure.We were impressed by the video quality of both the streaming videos and the games. Angry birds with the Roku remote is shockingly fun to play as a group. Speaking of which, the remote is probably the best remote I've ever used - much better than the wii's remotes.The whole family loves it, and I'd recommend it highly. In fact, we'll probably grab ourselves the Roku at some point.
summary: Pleasantly surprised by this little monster!
